<div id="contentSub"><div id="mw-content-subtitle"></div></div>





<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Capital and largest city of the United Kingdom</div>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1236090951">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article is about the capital city of England and the United Kingdom. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/London_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="London (disambiguation)">London (disambiguation)</a>.</div>

<p class="mw-empty-elt">







</p>

<p><b>London</b><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>c<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> is the <a href="/wiki/Capital_city" title="Capital city">capital</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of urban areas in the United Kingdom">largest city</a><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>d<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> of both <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, with a population of 8,866,180 in 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-ONS_mid-year_pop_est_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ONS_mid-year_pop_est-3"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/London_metropolitan_area" title="London metropolitan area">Its wider metropolitan area</a> is the largest in <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a>, with a population of 14.9&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London stands on the <a href="/wiki/River_Thames" title="River Thames">River Thames</a> in southeast England, at the head of a 50-mile (80&#160;km) <a href="/wiki/Tidal_estuary" class="mw-redirect" title="Tidal estuary">tidal estuary</a> down to the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a>, and has been a major settlement for nearly 2,000&#160;years.<sup id="cite_ref-london_001_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_001-12"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Its ancient core and <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial centre</a>, the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a>, was founded by the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Romans</a> as <a href="/wiki/Londinium" title="Londinium">Londinium</a> and has retained its medieval boundaries.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>e<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/City_of_Westminster" title="City of Westminster">City of Westminster</a>, to the west of the City of London, has been the centuries-long host of <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Government of the United Kingdom">the national government</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">parliament</a>. London grew rapidly <a href="/wiki/19th-century_London" title="19th-century London">in the 19th century</a>, becoming the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_throughout_history" title="List of largest cities throughout history">largest city at the time</a>. Since the 19th century,<sup id="cite_ref-Mills2_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mills2-15"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-chambers_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chambers-16"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the name "London" has referred to the <a href="/wiki/Metropolis" title="Metropolis">metropolis</a> around the City of London, historically split between the <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_England" title="Counties of England">counties</a> of <a href="/wiki/Middlesex" title="Middlesex">Middlesex</a>, <a href="/wiki/Essex" title="Essex">Essex</a>, <a href="/wiki/Surrey" title="Surrey">Surrey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kent" title="Kent">Kent</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hertfordshire" title="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-baffling_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-baffling-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which since 1965 has largely comprised the administrative area of <a href="/wiki/Greater_London" title="Greater London">Greater London</a>, governed by <a href="#Local_government">33 local authorities</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Authority" title="Greater London Authority">Greater London Authority</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>f<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-politics_uk2_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-politics_uk2-19"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>As one of the world's major <a href="/wiki/Global_cities" class="mw-redirect" title="Global cities">global cities</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London exerts a strong influence on world <a href="/wiki/Art_of_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Art of London">art</a>, entertainment, <a href="/wiki/Fashion_capital" title="Fashion capital">fashion</a>, commerce, finance, <a href="/wiki/Education_in_London" title="Education in London">education</a>, <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_London" title="Healthcare in London">healthcare</a>, <a href="/wiki/Media_in_London" title="Media in London">media</a>, science, technology, <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_London" title="Tourism in London">tourism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_London" title="Transport in London">transport</a>, and communications.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Despite a post-<a href="/wiki/Brexit" title="Brexit">Brexit</a> exodus of stock listings from the <a href="/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange" title="London Stock Exchange">London Stock Exchange</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-LSEExodusToNewYork_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LSEExodusToNewYork-24"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-LSEExodus_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LSEExodus-25"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London remains a European economic powerhouse,<sup id="cite_ref-London.gov.uk_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-London.gov.uk-26"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Global_Financial_Centres_Index" title="Global Financial Centres Index">one of the world's major financial centres</a>. It hosts Europe's largest concentration of <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_and_higher_education_colleges_in_London" title="List of universities and higher education colleges in London">higher education institutions</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-london2_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london2-27"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> some of which are the highest-ranked academic institutions in the world: <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_London" title="Imperial College London">Imperial College London</a> in <a href="/wiki/Natural_sciences" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural sciences">natural</a> and <a href="/wiki/Applied_science" title="Applied science">applied sciences</a>, the <a href="/wiki/London_School_of_Economics" title="London School of Economics">London School of Economics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Social_science" title="Social science">social sciences</a>, and the comprehensive <a href="/wiki/University_College_London" title="University College London">University College London</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_international_visitors" title="List of cities by international visitors">most visited city</a> in Europe and has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_busiest_city_airport_systems_by_passenger_traffic" title="List of busiest city airport systems by passenger traffic">busiest city airport system</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Busiest_skies_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Busiest_skies-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London Underground</a> is the world's oldest <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">rapid transit</a> system.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>London's diverse cultures encompass over 300 languages.<sup id="cite_ref-london_006_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_006-32"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The 2023 population of Greater London of just under 10&#160;million<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> made it Europe's <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_cities_by_population_within_city_limits" title="List of European cities by population within city limits">third-most populous city</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-largest_city_eu_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-largest_city_eu-34"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> accounting for 13.4% of the United Kingdom's population<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and over 16% of England's population. The <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Built-up_Area" title="Greater London Built-up Area">Greater London Built-up Area</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_Europe" title="List of urban areas in Europe">fourth-most populous</a> in Europe, with about 9.8&#160;million inhabitants as of 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-urbanpopulation_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-urbanpopulation-4"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Demographia_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Demographia-36"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The London metropolitan area is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Europe" title="List of metropolitan areas in Europe">third-most populous</a> in Europe, with about 14&#160;million inhabitants as of 2016, making London a <a href="/wiki/Megacity" title="Megacity">megacity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>g<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu_show_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu_show-38"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-gla-plan-2015_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gla-plan-2015-39"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Four <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a> are located in London: <a href="/wiki/Kew_Gardens" title="Kew Gardens">Kew Gardens</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Tower_of_London" title="Tower of London">Tower of London</a>; the site featuring the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a>, <a href="/wiki/St_Margaret%27s,_Westminster" title="St Margaret&#39;s, Westminster">Church of St. Margaret</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a>; and the historic settlement in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich" title="Greenwich">Greenwich</a> where the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich" title="Royal Observatory, Greenwich">Royal Observatory</a> defines the <a href="/wiki/Prime_meridian_(Greenwich)" title="Prime meridian (Greenwich)">prime meridian</a> (0° <a href="/wiki/Longitude" title="Longitude">longitude</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Mean_Time" title="Greenwich Mean Time">Greenwich Mean Time</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_005_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_005-40"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other landmarks include <a href="/wiki/Buckingham_Palace" title="Buckingham Palace">Buckingham Palace</a>, the <a href="/wiki/London_Eye" title="London Eye">London Eye</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piccadilly_Circus" title="Piccadilly Circus">Piccadilly Circus</a>, <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul&#39;s Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tower_Bridge" title="Tower Bridge">Tower Bridge</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Trafalgar_Square" title="Trafalgar Square">Trafalgar Square</a>. The city has the most <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_in_London" title="List of museums in London">museums</a>, art galleries, libraries, and cultural venues in the UK, including the <a href="/wiki/British_Museum" title="British Museum">British Museum</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery" title="National Gallery">National Gallery</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_London" title="Natural History Museum, London">Natural History Museum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tate_Modern" title="Tate Modern">Tate Modern</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Library" title="British Library">British Library</a>, and numerous <a href="/wiki/West_End_theatre" title="West End theatre">West End</a> theatres.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Important <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_London" title="Sport in London">sporting events held in London</a> include the <a href="/wiki/FA_Cup_Final" title="FA Cup Final">FA Cup Final</a>, the <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" class="mw-redirect" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon Tennis Championships</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/London_Marathon" title="London Marathon">London Marathon</a>. It became the first city to host three <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympic Games</a> upon hosting the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IOC_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IOC-42"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" /></div>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Toponymy">Toponymy</h2></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Etymology_of_London" title="Etymology of London">Etymology of London</a></div>

<p><i>London</i> is an ancient name, attested in the first century AD, usually in the <a href="/wiki/Latinisation_of_names" title="Latinisation of names">Latinised</a> form <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la"><a href="/wiki/Londinium" title="Londinium">Londinium</a></i></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-43"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Modern scientific analyses of the name must account for the origins of the different forms found in early sources: <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> (usually <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">Londinium</i></span>), <a href="/wiki/Old_English" title="Old English">Old English</a> (usually <span title="Old English (ca. 450-1100)-language text"><i lang="ang">Lunden</i></span>), and <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a> (usually <span title="Welsh-language text"><i lang="cy">Llundein</i></span>), with reference to the known developments over time of sounds in those different languages. It is agreed that the name came into these languages from <a href="/wiki/Common_Brittonic" title="Common Brittonic">Common Brythonic</a>; recent work tends to reconstruct the lost Celtic form of the name as <span title="Proto-Celtic-language text">&#42;<i lang="cel">Londonjon</i></span> or something similar. This was then adapted into Latin as <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">Londinium</i></span> and borrowed into Old English.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-44"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Until 1889, the name "London" applied officially only to the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a>, but since then it has also referred to the <a href="/wiki/County_of_London" title="County of London">County of London</a> and to <a href="/wiki/Greater_London" title="Greater London">Greater London</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="History">History</h2></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_London" title="History of London">History of London</a></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_London" title="Timeline of London">Timeline of London</a>.</div>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Prehistory">Prehistory</h3></div>

<p>In 1993, remains of a <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> bridge were found on the south River Thames <a href="/wiki/Foreshore" class="mw-redirect" title="Foreshore">foreshore</a>, upstream from <a href="/wiki/Vauxhall_Bridge" title="Vauxhall Bridge">Vauxhall Bridge</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Denison_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Denison-46"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Two of the timbers were <a href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating" title="Radiocarbon dating">radiocarbon dated</a> to 1750–1285&#160;BC.<sup id="cite_ref-Denison_46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Denison-46"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2010, foundations of a large timber structure, dated to 4800–4500&#160;BC,<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> were found on the Thames' south foreshore downstream from Vauxhall Bridge.<sup id="cite_ref-Milne_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Milne-48"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Both structures are on the south bank of the Thames, where the now-underground <a href="/wiki/River_Effra" title="River Effra">River Effra</a> flows into the Thames.<sup id="cite_ref-Milne_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Milne-48"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Roman_London">Roman London</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Londinium" title="Londinium">Londinium</a></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:219px;max-width:219px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:217px;max-width:217px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Reconstruction_drawing_of_Londinium_in_120_AD,_Museum_of_London_(34881481351).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Reconstruction_drawing_of_Londinium_in_120_AD%2C_Museum_of_London_%2834881481351%29.jpg/215px-Reconstruction_drawing_of_Londinium_in_120_AD%2C_Museum_of_London_%2834881481351%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="215" height="137" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Reconstruction_drawing_of_Londinium_in_120_AD%2C_Museum_of_London_%2834881481351%29.jpg/323px-Reconstruction_drawing_of_Londinium_in_120_AD%2C_Museum_of_London_%2834881481351%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Reconstruction_drawing_of_Londinium_in_120_AD%2C_Museum_of_London_%2834881481351%29.jpg/430px-Reconstruction_drawing_of_Londinium_in_120_AD%2C_Museum_of_London_%2834881481351%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3130" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">Reconstruction drawing of <a href="/wiki/Londinium" title="Londinium">Londinium</a> in 120 AD</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:217px;max-width:217px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:London_Wall_fragment.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/London_Wall_fragment.jpg/215px-London_Wall_fragment.jpg" decoding="async" width="215" height="161" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/London_Wall_fragment.jpg/323px-London_Wall_fragment.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/London_Wall_fragment.jpg/430px-London_Wall_fragment.jpg 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="563" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">A surviving section of the 3rd-century <a href="/wiki/London_Wall" title="London Wall">London Wall</a> behind <a href="/wiki/Tower_Hill" title="Tower Hill">Tower Hill</a></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>Despite the evidence of scattered <a href="/wiki/Celtic_Britons" title="Celtic Britons">Brythonic</a> settlements in the area, the first major settlement was founded by the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Romans</a> around 47&#160;AD,<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-1"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> about 4&#160;years after their invasion of 43&#160;AD.<sup id="cite_ref-roman_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roman-49"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This only lasted until about 61&#160;AD, when the <a href="/wiki/Iceni" title="Iceni">Iceni</a> tribe led by <a href="/wiki/Boudica" title="Boudica">Queen Boudica</a> stormed it and burnt it to the ground.<sup id="cite_ref-london_010_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_010-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>The next planned incarnation of <a href="/wiki/Londinium" title="Londinium">Londinium</a> prospered, superseding <a href="/wiki/Colchester" title="Colchester">Colchester</a> as the principal city of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_province" title="Roman province">Roman province</a> of <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">Britannia</a> in 100. At its height in the 2nd century, Roman London had a population of about 60,000.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Anglo-Saxon_and_Viking-period_London">Anglo-Saxon and Viking-period London</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_London" title="Anglo-Saxon London">Anglo-Saxon London</a></div>

<p>With the early 5th-century collapse of Roman rule, the walled city of Londinium was effectively abandoned, although <a href="/wiki/Roman_civilisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman civilisation">Roman civilisation</a> continued around <a href="/wiki/St_Martin-in-the-Fields" title="St Martin-in-the-Fields">St Martin-in-the-Fields</a> until about 450.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> From about 500, an <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglo-Saxon">Anglo-Saxon</a> settlement known as <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_London" title="Anglo-Saxon London">Lundenwic</a> developed slightly west of the old Roman city.<sup id="cite_ref-london_011_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_011-53"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> By about 680 the city had become a major port again, but there is little evidence of large-scale production. From the 820s repeated <a href="/wiki/Viking" class="mw-redirect" title="Viking">Viking</a> assaults brought decline. Three are recorded; those in 851 and 886 succeeded, while the last, in 994, was rebuffed.<sup id="cite_ref-Viking_Attacks_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Viking_Attacks-54"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>The Vikings applied <a href="/wiki/Danelaw" title="Danelaw">Danelaw</a> over much of eastern and northern England, its boundary running roughly from London to <a href="/wiki/Chester" title="Chester">Chester</a> as an area of political and geographical control imposed by the Viking incursions formally agreed by the <a href="/wiki/Danes" title="Danes">Danish</a> <a href="/wiki/Warlord" title="Warlord">warlord</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guthrum" title="Guthrum">Guthrum</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_West_Saxons" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of the West Saxons">West Saxon</a> king <a href="/wiki/Alfred_the_Great" title="Alfred the Great">Alfred the Great</a> in 886. The <i><a href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_Chronicle" title="Anglo-Saxon Chronicle">Anglo-Saxon Chronicle</a></i> records that Alfred "refounded" London in 886. Archaeological research shows this involved abandonment of Lundenwic and a revival of life and trade within the old <a href="/wiki/London_Wall" title="London Wall">Roman walls</a>. London then grew slowly until a dramatic increase in about 950.<sup id="cite_ref-blackwell_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-blackwell-55"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>By the 11th century, London was clearly the largest town in England. <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a>, rebuilt in <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_architecture" title="Romanesque architecture">Romanesque</a> style by King <a href="/wiki/Edward_the_Confessor" title="Edward the Confessor">Edward the Confessor</a>, was one of the grandest churches in Europe. <a href="/wiki/Winchester" title="Winchester">Winchester</a> had been the capital of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Anglo-Saxon_England" title="History of Anglo-Saxon England">Anglo-Saxon England</a>, but from this time London became the main forum for foreign traders and the base for defence in time of war. In the view of <a href="/wiki/Frank_Stenton" title="Frank Stenton">Frank Stenton</a>: "It had the resources, and it was rapidly developing the dignity and the political self-consciousness appropriate to a <a href="/wiki/National_capital" class="mw-redirect" title="National capital">national capital</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Middle_Ages">Middle Ages</h3></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto,_1749.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg/220px-Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="215" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg/330px-Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg/440px-Westminster_Abbey_by_Canaletto%2C_1749.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1008" data-file-height="984" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a>, as seen in this painting (<a href="/wiki/Canaletto" title="Canaletto">Canaletto</a>, 1749), is a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> and one of London's oldest and most important buildings.</figcaption></figure>

<p>After winning the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hastings" title="Battle of Hastings">Battle of Hastings</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_the_Conqueror" title="William the Conqueror">William, Duke of Normandy</a> was crowned <a href="/wiki/King_of_England" class="mw-redirect" title="King of England">King of England</a> in the newly completed <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a> on Christmas Day 1066.<sup id="cite_ref-london_015_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_015-57"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> William built the <a href="/wiki/Tower_of_London" title="Tower of London">Tower of London</a>, the first of many such in England rebuilt in stone in the south-eastern corner of the city, to intimidate the inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-london_016_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_016-58"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1097, <a href="/wiki/William_II_of_England" title="William II of England">William II</a> began building <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Hall" title="Westminster Hall">Westminster Hall</a>, near the abbey. It became the basis of a new <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_017_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_017-59"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>In the 12th century, the institutions of central government, which had hitherto followed the royal English court around the country, grew in size and sophistication and became increasingly fixed, for most purposes at <a href="/wiki/Westminster" title="Westminster">Westminster</a>, although the royal treasury came to rest in the <a href="/wiki/Tower_of_London" title="Tower of London">Tower</a>. While the <a href="/wiki/Westminster" title="Westminster">City of Westminster</a> developed into a true governmental capital, its distinct neighbour, the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a>, remained England's largest city and principal commercial centre and flourished under its own unique administration, the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation" title="City of London Corporation">Corporation of London</a>. In 1100, its population was some 18,000; by 1300 it had grown to nearly 100,000.<sup id="cite_ref-london_019_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_019-60"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> With the <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">Black Death</a> in the mid-14th century, London lost nearly a third of its population.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London was the focus of the <a href="/wiki/Peasants%27_Revolt" title="Peasants&#39; Revolt">Peasants' Revolt</a> in 1381.<sup id="cite_ref-london_020_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_020-62"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>London was a centre of England's <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_England_(1066%E2%80%931290)" title="History of the Jews in England (1066–1290)">Jewish population</a> before their <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Expulsion" title="Edict of Expulsion">expulsion</a> by <a href="/wiki/Edward_I_of_England" title="Edward I of England">Edward I</a> in 1290. Violence against Jews occurred in 1190, when it was rumoured that the new king had ordered their massacre after they had presented themselves at his coronation.<sup id="cite_ref-Jacobs_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jacobs-63"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1264 during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Barons%27_War" title="Second Barons&#39; War">Second Barons' War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Simon_de_Montfort,_6th_Earl_of_Leicester" title="Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester">Simon de Montfort</a>'s rebels killed 500 Jews while attempting to seize records of debts.<sup id="cite_ref-Mundill2010_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mundill2010-64"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Early_modern">Early modern</h3></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Siege_of_London_(MS_1168).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Siege_of_London_%28MS_1168%29.jpg/170px-Siege_of_London_%28MS_1168%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="259" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Siege_of_London_%28MS_1168%29.jpg/255px-Siege_of_London_%28MS_1168%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d3/Siege_of_London_%28MS_1168%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="320" data-file-height="488" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/House_of_Lancaster" title="House of Lancaster">Lancastrian</a> siege of London in 1471 is attacked by a <a href="/wiki/House_of_York" title="House of York">Yorkist</a> sally.</figcaption></figure>

<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Tudor_period" title="Tudor period">Tudor period</a>, the <a href="/wiki/English_Reformation" title="English Reformation">Reformation</a> produced a gradual shift to <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a>. Much of London property passed from church to private ownership, which accelerated trade and business in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-pevsner_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pevsner-65"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1475, the <a href="/wiki/Hanseatic_League" title="Hanseatic League">Hanseatic League</a> set up a main trading base (<i><a href="/wiki/Kontor" title="Kontor">kontor</a></i>) of England in London, called the <i>Stalhof</i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Steelyard" title="Steelyard">Steelyard</a></i>. It remained until 1853, when the Hanseatic cities of <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BCbeck" title="Lübeck">Lübeck</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bremen" title="Bremen">Bremen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hamburg" title="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> sold the property to <a href="/wiki/South_Eastern_Railway,_UK" class="mw-redirect" title="South Eastern Railway, UK">South Eastern Railway</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EB_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB-66"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Woollen" class="mw-redirect" title="Woollen">Woollen</a> cloth was shipped undyed and undressed from 14th/15th century London to the nearby shores of the <a href="/wiki/Low_Countries" title="Low Countries">Low Countries</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Yet English maritime enterprise hardly reached beyond the seas of <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_Europe" title="Northwestern Europe">north-west Europe</a>. The commercial route to Italy and the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> was normally through <a href="/wiki/Antwerp" title="Antwerp">Antwerp</a> and over the <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a>; any ships passing through the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar" title="Strait of Gibraltar">Strait of Gibraltar</a> to or from England were likely to be Italian or <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ragusa" title="Republic of Ragusa">Ragusan</a>. The reopening of the Netherlands to English shipping in January 1565 spurred a burst of commercial activity.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Exchange,_London" title="Royal Exchange, London">Royal Exchange</a> was founded.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mercantilism" title="Mercantilism">Mercantilism</a> grew and monopoly traders such as the <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">East India Company</a> were founded as trade expanded to the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a>. London became the main <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a> port, with migrants arriving from England and abroad. The population rose from about 50,000 in 1530 to about 225,000 in 1605.<sup id="cite_ref-pevsner_65-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pevsner-65"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg/220px-London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="207" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg/330px-London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg/440px-London_-_John_Norden%27s_map_of_1593.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3760" /></a><figcaption>Map of London in 1593. There is only one bridge across the Thames, but parts of Southwark on the south bank of the river have been developed.</figcaption></figure>

<p>In the 16th century, <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a> and his contemporaries lived in London during <a href="/wiki/English_Renaissance_theatre" title="English Renaissance theatre">English Renaissance theatre</a>. Shakespeare's <a href="/wiki/Globe_Theatre" title="Globe Theatre">Globe Theatre</a> was constructed in 1599 in <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Southwark" title="London Borough of Southwark">Southwark</a>. Stage performances came to a halt in London when <a href="/wiki/Puritan" class="mw-redirect" title="Puritan">Puritan</a> authorities <a href="/wiki/London_theatre_closure_1642" title="London theatre closure 1642">shut down the theatres</a> in the 1640s.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The ban on theatre was lifted during <a href="/wiki/Stuart_Restoration" title="Stuart Restoration">the Restoration</a> in 1660, and London's oldest operating theatre, <a href="/wiki/Theatre_Royal,_Drury_Lane" title="Theatre Royal, Drury Lane">Drury Lane</a>, opened in 1663 in what is now the <a href="/wiki/West_End_theatre" title="West End theatre">West End</a> theatre district.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>By the end of the Tudor period in 1603, London was still compact. There was an assassination attempt on <a href="/wiki/James_I_of_England" class="mw-redirect" title="James I of England">James I</a> in Westminster, in the <a href="/wiki/Gunpowder_Plot" title="Gunpowder Plot">Gunpowder Plot</a> of 5 November 1605.<sup id="cite_ref-london_023_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_023-72"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1637, the government of <a href="/wiki/Charles_I_of_England" title="Charles I of England">Charles I</a> attempted to reform administration in the London area. This called for the Corporation of the city to extend its jurisdiction and administration over expanding areas around the city. Fearing an attempt by the Crown to diminish the <a href="/wiki/Liberties_of_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Liberties of London">Liberties of London</a>, coupled with a lack of interest in administering these additional areas or concern by city guilds of having to share power, caused the Corporation's "The Great Refusal", a decision which largely continues to account for the unique governmental status of the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Great_Fire_London.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Great_Fire_London.jpg/260px-Great_Fire_London.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="151" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Great_Fire_London.jpg/390px-Great_Fire_London.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Great_Fire_London.jpg/520px-Great_Fire_London.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5477" data-file-height="3189" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London" title="Great Fire of London">Great Fire of London</a> destroyed many parts of the city in 1666.</figcaption></figure>

<p>In the <a href="/wiki/English_Civil_War" title="English Civil War">English Civil War</a>, the majority of Londoners supported the <a href="/wiki/Roundhead" title="Roundhead">Parliamentary</a> cause. After an initial advance by the <a href="/wiki/Cavaliers" class="mw-redirect" title="Cavaliers">Royalists</a> in 1642, culminating in the battles of <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Brentford_(1642)" title="Battle of Brentford (1642)">Brentford</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Turnham_Green" title="Battle of Turnham Green">Turnham Green</a>, London was surrounded by a defensive perimeter wall known as the <a href="/wiki/Lines_of_Communication_(London)" title="Lines of Communication (London)">Lines of Communication</a>. The lines were built by up to 20,000 people, and were completed in under two months.<sup id="cite_ref-fortified_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fortified-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The fortifications failed their only test when the <a href="/wiki/New_Model_Army" title="New Model Army">New Model Army</a> entered London in 1647,<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and they were levelled by Parliament the same year.<sup id="cite_ref-fortified_74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fortified-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London was <a href="/wiki/Bubonic_plague" title="Bubonic plague">plagued</a> by disease in the early 17th century,<sup id="cite_ref-london_024_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_024-77"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Great_Plague_of_London" title="Great Plague of London">Great Plague</a> of 1665–1666, which killed up to 100,000 people, or a fifth of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-london_024_77-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_024-77"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London" title="Great Fire of London">Great Fire of London</a> broke out in 1666 in Pudding Lane in the city and quickly swept through the wooden buildings.<sup id="cite_ref-Samuel_Pepys&#39;_Diary_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Samuel_Pepys&#39;_Diary-78"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Rebuilding took over 10&#160;years and was supervised by polymath <a href="/wiki/Robert_Hooke" title="Robert Hooke">Robert Hooke</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_026_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_026-79"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Edward_Angelo_Goodall04.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Edward_Angelo_Goodall04.jpg/170px-Edward_Angelo_Goodall04.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Edward_Angelo_Goodall04.jpg/255px-Edward_Angelo_Goodall04.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Edward_Angelo_Goodall04.jpg/340px-Edward_Angelo_Goodall04.jpg 2x" data-file-width="599" data-file-height="799" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul&#39;s Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a> (painted by <a href="/wiki/Edward_Angelo_Goodall" title="Edward Angelo Goodall">Edward Goodall</a> in 1850) was completed in 1710</figcaption></figure>

<p>In 1710, <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Wren" title="Christopher Wren">Christopher Wren</a>'s masterpiece, <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul&#39;s Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a>, was completed, replacing its medieval predecessor that burned in the Great Fire of 1666. The dome of St Paul's dominated the London skyline for centuries, inspiring the artworks and writing of <a href="/wiki/William_Blake" title="William Blake">William Blake</a>, with his 1789 poem "<a href="/wiki/Holy_Thursday_(Songs_of_Innocence)" title="Holy Thursday (Songs of Innocence)">Holy Thursday</a>" referring to 'the high dome of Pauls'.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Georgian_era" title="Georgian era">Georgian era</a>, new districts such as <a href="/wiki/Mayfair" title="Mayfair">Mayfair</a> were formed in the west; new bridges over the Thames encouraged development in <a href="/wiki/South_London" title="South London">South London</a>. In the east, the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_London" title="Port of London">Port of London</a> expanded downstream. London's development as an international <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial centre</a> matured for much of the 18th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Finance_Hub_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Finance_Hub-81"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>In 1762, <a href="/wiki/George_III_of_Great_Britain" class="mw-redirect" title="George III of Great Britain">George III</a> acquired <a href="/wiki/Buckingham_Palace" title="Buckingham Palace">Buckingham House</a>, which was enlarged over the next 75&#160;years. During the 18th century, London was said to be dogged by crime,<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Bow_Street_Runners" title="Bow Street Runners">Bow Street Runners</a> were established in 1750 as a professional police force.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Epidemics during the 1720s and 30s saw most children born in the city die before reaching their fifth birthday.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p><a href="/wiki/Coffeehouse" title="Coffeehouse">Coffee-houses</a> became a popular place to debate ideas, as growing <a href="/wiki/Literacy" title="Literacy">literacy</a> and development of the <a href="/wiki/Printing_press" title="Printing press">printing press</a> made news widely available, with <a href="/wiki/Fleet_Street" title="Fleet Street">Fleet Street</a> becoming the centre of the British press. The invasion of Amsterdam by Napoleonic armies led many financiers to relocate to London and the first London international issue was arranged in 1817. Around the same time, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> became the world's leading war fleet, acting as a major deterrent to potential economic adversaries. Following a fire in 1838, the Royal Exchange was redesigned by <a href="/wiki/William_Tite" title="William Tite">William Tite</a> and rebuilt in 1844. The repeal of the <a href="/wiki/Corn_Laws" title="Corn Laws">Corn Laws</a> in 1846 was specifically aimed at weakening Dutch economic power. London then overtook Amsterdam as the leading international financial centre.<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-85"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Late_modern_and_contemporary">Late modern and contemporary</h3></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London,_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif/lossy-page1-220px-Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="182" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif/lossy-page1-330px-Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif/lossy-page1-440px-Fotografi_av_Royal_Exchange._London%2C_England_-_Hallwylska_museet_-_105857.tif.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4135" data-file-height="3418" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Exchange,_London" title="Royal Exchange, London">Royal Exchange</a> in 1886. It was founded in 1571 (with the present building rebuilt in 1844) as a centre of commerce for the City of London.</figcaption></figure>

<p>With the onset of the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> in Britain, an unprecedented growth in <a href="/wiki/Urbanisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Urbanisation">urbanisation</a> took place, and the number of <a href="/wiki/High_Street" title="High Street">High Streets</a> (the primary street for retail in Britain) rapidly grew.<sup id="cite_ref-Sales_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sales-86"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London was the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_throughout_history" title="List of largest cities throughout history">largest city from about 1831 to 1925</a>, with a population density of 802 per acre (325 per hectare).<sup id="cite_ref-london_030_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_030-88"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In addition to the growing number of stores selling goods, such as <a href="/wiki/Harding,_Howell_%26_Co." title="Harding, Howell &amp; Co.">Harding, Howell &amp; Co.</a>—one of the first <a href="/wiki/Department_store" title="Department store">department stores</a>—located on <a href="/wiki/Pall_Mall,_London" title="Pall Mall, London">Pall Mall</a>, the streets had scores of <a href="/wiki/Hawker_(trade)" title="Hawker (trade)">street sellers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sales_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sales-86"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London's overcrowded conditions led to <a href="/wiki/Cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a> epidemics, claiming 14,000 lives in 1848, and 6,000 in 1866.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Rising <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">traffic congestion</a> led to the creation of the <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London Underground</a>, the world's first <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">urban rail network</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Board_of_Works" title="Metropolitan Board of Works">Metropolitan Board of Works</a> oversaw infrastructure expansion in the capital and some surrounding counties; it was abolished in 1889 when the <a href="/wiki/London_County_Council" title="London County Council">London County Council</a> was created out of county areas surrounding the capital.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>From the early years of the 20th century onwards, <a href="/wiki/Tea_in_the_United_Kingdom#Tea_rooms" title="Tea in the United Kingdom">teashops</a> were found on High Streets across London and the rest of Britain, with <a href="/wiki/J._Lyons_and_Co." title="J. Lyons and Co.">Lyons</a>, who opened the first of their <a href="/wiki/Chain_store" title="Chain store">chain</a> of teashops in <a href="/wiki/Piccadilly" title="Piccadilly">Piccadilly</a> in 1894, leading the way.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The tearooms, such as the <a href="/wiki/Criterion_Restaurant" title="Criterion Restaurant">Criterion</a> in Piccadilly, became a popular meeting place for women from the suffrage movement.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The city was the target of many attacks during the <a href="/wiki/Suffragette_bombing_and_arson_campaign" title="Suffragette bombing and arson campaign">suffragette bombing and arson campaign</a>, between 1912 and 1914, which saw historic landmarks such as <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a> and <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul&#39;s Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a> bombed.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg/220px-British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="159" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg/330px-British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg/440px-British_recruits_August_1914_Q53234.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3442" data-file-height="2480" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">British volunteer recruits in London, August 1914, during <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg/220px-LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="157" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg/330px-LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg/440px-LondonBombedWWII_full.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1968" data-file-height="1406" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">A bombed-out London street during <a href="/wiki/The_Blitz" title="The Blitz">the Blitz</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a></div></div></div></div></div>

<p><span class="anchor" id="German_air_attacks"></span>London was <a href="/wiki/German_strategic_bombing_during_World_War_I" class="mw-redirect" title="German strategic bombing during World War I">bombed by the Germans</a> in the <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="First World War">First World War</a>, and during the <a href="/wiki/Second_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Second World War">Second World War</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Blitz" title="The Blitz">the Blitz</a> and other bombings by the German <i><a href="/wiki/Luftwaffe" title="Luftwaffe">Luftwaffe</a></i> killed over 30,000 Londoners, destroying large tracts of housing and other buildings across the city.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The tomb of <a href="/wiki/The_Unknown_Warrior" title="The Unknown Warrior">the Unknown Warrior</a>, an unidentified member of the British armed forces killed during the First World War, was buried in Westminster Abbey on 11 November 1920.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/The_Cenotaph" title="The Cenotaph">The Cenotaph</a>, located in <a href="/wiki/Whitehall" title="Whitehall">Whitehall</a>, was unveiled on the same day, and is the focal point for the <a href="/wiki/National_Service_of_Remembrance" title="National Service of Remembrance">National Service of Remembrance</a> held annually on <a href="/wiki/Remembrance_Sunday" title="Remembrance Sunday">Remembrance Sunday</a>, the closest Sunday to 11 November.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/1948_Summer_Olympics" title="1948 Summer Olympics">1948 Summer Olympics</a> were held at the original <a href="/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_(1923)" title="Wembley Stadium (1923)">Wembley Stadium</a>, while London was still recovering from the war.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> From the 1940s, London became home to many immigrants, primarily from <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth</a> countries such as Jamaica, India, Bangladesh and Pakistan,<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> making London one of the most diverse cities in the world. In 1951, the <a href="/wiki/Festival_of_Britain" title="Festival of Britain">Festival of Britain</a> was held on the <a href="/wiki/South_Bank" title="South Bank">South Bank</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Great_Smog" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Smog">Great Smog</a> of 1952 led to the <a href="/wiki/Clean_Air_Act_1956" title="Clean Air Act 1956">Clean Air Act 1956</a>, which ended the "<a href="/wiki/Pea_soup_fog" title="Pea soup fog">pea soup fogs</a>" for which London had been notorious, and had earned it the nickname the "Big Smoke".<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Starting mainly in the mid-1960s, London became a centre for worldwide <a href="/wiki/Youth_culture" title="Youth culture">youth culture</a>, exemplified by the <a href="/wiki/Swinging_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Swinging London">Swinging London</a> sub-culture associated with the <a href="/wiki/King%27s_Road" title="King&#39;s Road">King's Road</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chelsea,_London" title="Chelsea, London">Chelsea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carnaby_Street" title="Carnaby Street">Carnaby Street</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The role of trendsetter revived in the <a href="/wiki/Punk_rock" title="Punk rock">punk</a> era.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1965 London's political boundaries were expanded in response to the growth of the urban area and a new <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Council" title="Greater London Council">Greater London Council</a> was created.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During <a href="/wiki/The_Troubles" title="The Troubles">The Troubles</a> in Northern Ireland, London was hit from 1973 by bomb attacks by the <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Irish_Republican_Army" title="Provisional Irish Republican Army">Provisional Irish Republican Army</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bombings_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bombings-105"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> These attacks lasted for two decades, starting with the <a href="/wiki/Old_Bailey_bombing" class="mw-redirect" title="Old Bailey bombing">Old Bailey bombing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bombings_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bombings-105"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Racial inequality was highlighted by the <a href="/wiki/1981_Brixton_riot" title="1981 Brixton riot">1981 Brixton riot</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Greater London's population declined in the decades after the Second World War, from an estimated peak of 8.6&#160;million in 1939 to around 6.8&#160;million in the 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The principal ports for London moved downstream to <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Felixstowe" title="Port of Felixstowe">Felixstowe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Tilbury" title="Port of Tilbury">Tilbury</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/London_Docklands" title="London Docklands">London Docklands</a> area becoming a focus for regeneration, including the <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a> development. This was born out of London's increasing role as an international financial centre in the 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Located about 2&#160;miles (3&#160;km) east of central London, the <a href="/wiki/Thames_Barrier" title="Thames Barrier">Thames Barrier</a> was completed in the 1980s to protect London against tidal surges from the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>The Greater London Council was abolished in 1986, leaving London with no central administration until 2000 and the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Authority" title="Greater London Authority">Greater London Authority</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> To mark the 21st century, the <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Dome" title="Millennium Dome">Millennium Dome</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Eye" title="London Eye">London Eye</a> and <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Bridge_(London)" class="mw-redirect" title="Millennium Bridge (London)">Millennium Bridge</a> were constructed.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>104<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 6 July 2005 London was awarded the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>, as the first city to stage the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a> three times.<sup id="cite_ref-IOC_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IOC-42"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 7 July 2005, three London Underground trains and a double-decker bus were bombed in a <a href="/wiki/7_July_2005_London_bombings" title="7 July 2005 London bombings">series of terrorist attacks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bombings_105-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bombings-105"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>In 2008, <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> named London alongside New York City and Hong Kong as <a href="/wiki/Nylonkong" title="Nylonkong">Nylonkong</a>, hailing them as the world's three most influential <a href="/wiki/Global_cities" class="mw-redirect" title="Global cities">global cities</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>105<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In January 2015, Greater London's population was estimated to be 8.63&#160;million, its highest since 1939.<sup id="cite_ref-gla-pop-2015_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gla-pop-2015-113"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/2016_United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum" title="2016 United Kingdom European Union membership referendum">Brexit referendum</a> in 2016, the UK as a whole decided to leave the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, but most London constituencies voted for remaining.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, Britain's <a href="/wiki/Brexit" title="Brexit">exit from the EU</a> in early 2020 only marginally weakened London's position as an international financial centre.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Administration">Administration</h2></div>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Local_government">Local government</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_London" title="Local government in London">Local government in London</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_local_government_in_London" title="History of local government in London">History of local government in London</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_heads_of_London_government" title="List of heads of London government">List of heads of London government</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:City_coat_of_arms,_Holborn_Viaduct_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/City_coat_of_arms%2C_Holborn_Viaduct_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-City_coat_of_arms%2C_Holborn_Viaduct_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/City_coat_of_arms%2C_Holborn_Viaduct_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-City_coat_of_arms%2C_Holborn_Viaduct_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/City_coat_of_arms%2C_Holborn_Viaduct_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-City_coat_of_arms%2C_Holborn_Viaduct_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1275" data-file-height="1021" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_the_City_of_London" title="Coat of arms of the City of London">Arms of the Corporation of the City of London</a><sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>

<p>The administration of London is formed of two tiers: a citywide, strategic tier and a local tier. Citywide administration is coordinated by the <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Authority" title="Greater London Authority">Greater London Authority</a> (GLA), while local administration is carried out by 33 smaller authorities.<sup id="cite_ref-london_032_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_032-117"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The GLA consists of two elected components: the <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_London" title="Mayor of London">mayor of London</a>, who has <a href="/wiki/Executive_powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Executive powers">executive powers</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/London_Assembly" title="London Assembly">London Assembly</a>, which scrutinises the mayor's decisions and can accept or reject the mayor's budget proposals each year. The GLA has responsibility for the majority of London's transport system through its functional arm <a href="/wiki/Transport_for_London" title="Transport for London">Transport for London</a> (TfL), it is responsible for overseeing the city's police and fire services, and also for setting a strategic vision for London on a range of issues.<sup id="cite_ref-london_goverance_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_goverance-118"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The headquarters of the GLA is <a href="/wiki/City_Hall,_Newham" class="mw-redirect" title="City Hall, Newham">City Hall</a>, Newham. The mayor since 2016 has been <a href="/wiki/Sadiq_Khan" title="Sadiq Khan">Sadiq Khan</a>, the first <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> mayor of a major Western capital.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The mayor's <a href="/wiki/Statutory_planning" class="mw-redirect" title="Statutory planning">statutory planning</a> strategy is published as the <a href="/wiki/London_Plan" title="London Plan">London Plan</a>, which was most recently revised in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-london_plan_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_plan-120"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>The local authorities are the councils of the 32 <a href="/wiki/London_boroughs" title="London boroughs">London boroughs</a> and the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation" title="City of London Corporation">City of London Corporation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_035_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_035-121"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> They are responsible for most local services, such as local planning, schools, libraries, leisure and recreation, <a href="/wiki/Social_work" title="Social work">social services</a>, local roads and refuse collection.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Certain functions, such as <a href="/wiki/Waste_disposal_authorities_in_London" title="Waste disposal authorities in London">waste management</a>, are provided through joint arrangements. In 2009–2010 the combined revenue expenditure by London councils and the GLA amounted to just over £22&#160;billion (£14.7&#160;billion for the boroughs and £7.4&#160;billion for the GLA).<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/London_Fire_Brigade" title="London Fire Brigade">London Fire Brigade</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Statute" title="Statute">statutory</a> <a href="/wiki/Fire_service_in_the_UK" class="mw-redirect" title="Fire service in the UK">fire and rescue service</a> for Greater London, run by the <a href="/wiki/London_Fire_and_Emergency_Planning_Authority" title="London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority">London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority</a>. It is the third largest fire service in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-LFB_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LFB-124"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Service" title="National Health Service">National Health Service</a> <a href="/wiki/Emergency_medical_services" title="Emergency medical services">ambulance services</a> are provided by the <a href="/wiki/London_Ambulance_Service" title="London Ambulance Service">London Ambulance Service (LAS) NHS Trust</a>, the largest free-at-the-point-of-use emergency ambulance service in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-LAS_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LAS-125"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/London_Air_Ambulance" class="mw-redirect" title="London Air Ambulance">London Air Ambulance</a> charity operates in conjunction with the LAS where required. <a href="/wiki/Her_Majesty%27s_Coastguard" class="mw-redirect" title="Her Majesty&#39;s Coastguard">Her Majesty's Coastguard</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Royal_National_Lifeboat_Institution" title="Royal National Lifeboat Institution">Royal National Lifeboat Institution</a> operate on the <a href="/wiki/River_Thames" title="River Thames">River Thames</a>, which is under the jurisdiction of the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_London_Authority" title="Port of London Authority">Port of London Authority</a> from <a href="/wiki/Teddington_Lock" title="Teddington Lock">Teddington Lock</a> to the sea.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="National_government">National government</h3></div>
