<figure class="mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg/190px-10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="237" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg/285px-10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg/380px-10_Downing_Street._MOD_45155532_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1392" data-file-height="1738" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/10_Downing_Street" title="10 Downing Street">10 Downing Street</a>, official residence of the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">Prime Minister</a></figcaption></figure>

<p>London is the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Government of the United Kingdom">Government of the United Kingdom</a>. Many government departments, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">prime minister's</a> residence at <a href="/wiki/10_Downing_Street" title="10 Downing Street">10 Downing Street</a>, are based close to the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a>, particularly along <a href="/wiki/Whitehall" title="Whitehall">Whitehall</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_036_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_036-127"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are 75 members of <a href="/wiki/British_House_of_Commons" class="mw-redirect" title="British House of Commons">Parliament</a> (MPs) from London; As of <a href="/wiki/2024_United_Kingdom_general_election" title="2024 United Kingdom general election">June 2024</a>, 59 are from the <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">Labour Party</a>, 9 are <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)" title="Conservative Party (UK)">Conservatives</a>, 6 are <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Democrats_(UK)" title="Liberal Democrats (UK)">Liberal Democrats</a> and one constituency is held by an <a href="/wiki/Independent_politician" title="Independent politician">independent</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The ministerial post of <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_London" title="Minister for London">minister for London</a> was created in 1994, however as of 2024, the post has been vacant.

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Policing_and_crime">Policing and crime</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_London" title="Crime in London">Crime in London</a></div>

<p>Policing in Greater London, with the exception of the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a>, is provided by the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Police" title="Metropolitan Police">Metropolitan Police</a> ("The Met"), overseen by the mayor through the <a href="/wiki/Mayor%27s_Office_for_Policing_and_Crime" title="Mayor&#39;s Office for Policing and Crime">Mayor's Office for Policing and Crime</a> (MOPAC).<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Met is also referred to as <a href="/wiki/Scotland_Yard" title="Scotland Yard">Scotland Yard</a> after the location of its original headquarters in a road called <a href="/wiki/Great_Scotland_Yard" title="Great Scotland Yard">Great Scotland Yard</a> in Whitehall. The City of London has its own police force&#160;– the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London_Police" title="City of London Police">City of London Police</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Policing_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Policing-130"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> First worn by Met police officers in 1863, the <a href="/wiki/Custodian_helmet" title="Custodian helmet">custodian helmet</a> has been called a "cultural icon" and a "symbol of British law enforcement".<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Introduced by the Met in 1929, the blue <a href="/wiki/Police_box" title="Police box">police telephone box</a> (basis for the <a href="/wiki/TARDIS" title="TARDIS">TARDIS</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Who" title="Doctor Who">Doctor Who</a></i>) was once a common sight throughout London and regional cities in the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>125<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:SIS_building_(26327425611).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/SIS_building_%2826327425611%29.jpg/240px-SIS_building_%2826327425611%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="160" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/SIS_building_%2826327425611%29.jpg/360px-SIS_building_%2826327425611%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/SIS_building_%2826327425611%29.jpg/480px-SIS_building_%2826327425611%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2715" data-file-height="1810" /></a><figcaption>Headquarters of <a href="/wiki/MI6" title="MI6">MI6</a>, the UK's foreign intelligence service, at the <a href="/wiki/SIS_Building" title="SIS Building">SIS Building</a>. Scenes featuring <a href="/wiki/James_Bond" title="James Bond">James Bond</a> (the fictional MI6 agent) have been filmed here.</figcaption></figure>

<p>The <a href="/wiki/British_Transport_Police" title="British Transport Police">British Transport Police</a> are responsible for police services on <a href="/wiki/National_Rail" title="National Rail">National Rail</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London Underground</a>, <a href="/wiki/Docklands_Light_Railway" title="Docklands Light Railway">Docklands Light Railway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tramlink" title="Tramlink">Tramlink</a> services.<sup id="cite_ref-BTP_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BTP-133"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_Police" title="Ministry of Defence Police">Ministry of Defence Police</a> is a special police force in London, which does not generally become involved with policing the general public.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The UK's domestic counter-intelligence service (<a href="/wiki/MI5" title="MI5">MI5</a>) is headquartered in <a href="/wiki/Thames_House" title="Thames House">Thames House</a> on the north bank of the River Thames and the foreign intelligence service (<a href="/wiki/MI6" title="MI6">MI6</a>) is headquartered in the <a href="/wiki/SIS_Building" title="SIS Building">SIS Building</a> on the south bank.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Crime rates vary widely across different areas of London. Crime figures are made available nationally at <a href="/wiki/Local_authority#England" class="mw-redirect" title="Local authority">Local Authority</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ward_(England)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ward (England)">Ward</a> level.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>129<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2015, there were 118 homicides, a 25.5% increase over 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

Recorded crime has been rising in London, notably violent crime and murder by stabbing and other means have risen. There were 50 murders from the start of 2018 to mid April 2018. Funding cuts to police in London are likely to have contributed to this, though other factors are involved.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>131<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, homicide figures fell in 2022 with 109 recorded for the year, and the murder rate in London is much lower than <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_homicide_rate" title="List of cities by homicide rate">other major cities</a> around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>132<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Geography">Geography</h2></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_London" title="Geography of London">Geography of London</a></div>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Scope">Scope</h3></div>

<p>London, also known as <a href="/wiki/Greater_London" title="Greater London">Greater London</a>, is one of nine <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_England" title="Regions of England">regions of England</a> and the top subdivision covering most of the city's metropolis. The <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a> at its core once comprised the whole settlement, but as its urban area grew, the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London_Corporation" title="City of London Corporation">Corporation of London</a> resisted attempts to amalgamate the city with its <a href="/wiki/Suburbs" class="mw-redirect" title="Suburbs">suburbs</a>, causing "London" to be defined several ways.<sup id="cite_ref-chancery_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chancery-140"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>133<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/220px-London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="166" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/330px-London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/440px-London_by_Sentinel-2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7368" data-file-height="5576" /></a><figcaption>Satellite view of London in June 2018</figcaption></figure>

<p>Forty percent of Greater London is covered by the <a href="/wiki/London_postal_district" title="London postal district">London post town</a>, in which 'London' forms part of postal addresses.<sup id="cite_ref-london_042_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_042-141"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>134<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The London telephone <a href="/wiki/Area_code" class="mw-redirect" title="Area code">area code</a> (020) covers a larger area, similar in size to Greater London, although some outer districts are excluded and some just outside included. The Greater London boundary has been <a href="/wiki/List_of_Greater_London_boundary_changes" title="List of Greater London boundary changes">aligned to the M25 motorway</a> in places.<sup id="cite_ref-london_044_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_044-142"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>135<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Further urban expansion is now prevented by the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Green_Belt" title="Metropolitan Green Belt">Metropolitan Green Belt</a>, although the built-up area extends beyond the boundary in places, producing a separately defined <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Urban_Area" class="mw-redirect" title="Greater London Urban Area">Greater London Urban Area</a>. Beyond this is the vast <a href="/wiki/London_commuter_belt" class="mw-redirect" title="London commuter belt">London commuter belt</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_041_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_041-143"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>136<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Greater London is split for some purposes into <a href="/wiki/Inner_London" title="Inner London">Inner London</a> and <a href="/wiki/Outer_London" title="Outer London">Outer London</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-london_045_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_045-144"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>137<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and by the River Thames into <a href="/wiki/North_London" title="North London">North</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_London" title="South London">South</a>, with an informal <a href="/wiki/Central_London" title="Central London">central London</a> area. The coordinates of the nominal centre of London, traditionally the original <a href="/wiki/Eleanor_Cross" class="mw-redirect" title="Eleanor Cross">Eleanor Cross</a> at <a href="/wiki/Charing_Cross" title="Charing Cross">Charing Cross</a> near the junction of <a href="/wiki/Trafalgar_Square" title="Trafalgar Square">Trafalgar Square</a> and <a href="/wiki/Whitehall" title="Whitehall">Whitehall</a>, are about <span class="geo-inline"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1156832818"><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=London&amp;params=51_30_26_N_00_07_39_W_type:city(7,000,000)_region:GB"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">51°30′26″N</span> <span class="longitude">00°07′39″W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">&#xfeff; / &#xfeff;</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">51.50722°N 0.12750°W</span><span style="display:none">&#xfeff; / <span class="geo">51.50722; -0.12750</span></span></span></a></span></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_039_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_039-145"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Status">Status</h3></div>

<p>Within London, both the City of London and the <a href="/wiki/City_of_Westminster" title="City of Westminster">City of Westminster</a> have <a href="/wiki/City_status_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="City status in the United Kingdom">city status</a>. The City of London and the remainder of Greater London are both <a href="/wiki/Ceremonial_counties_of_England" title="Ceremonial counties of England">counties for the purposes of lieutenancies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_049_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_049-146"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The area of <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_and_non-metropolitan_counties_of_England#Greater_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Metropolitan and non-metropolitan counties of England">Greater London</a> includes areas that are part of the <a href="/wiki/Historic_counties_of_England" title="Historic counties of England">historic counties</a> of <a href="/wiki/Middlesex" title="Middlesex">Middlesex</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kent" title="Kent">Kent</a>, <a href="/wiki/Surrey" title="Surrey">Surrey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Essex" title="Essex">Essex</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hertfordshire" title="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_050_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_050-147"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>140<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> More recently, Greater London has been defined as a <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_England" title="Regions of England">region of England</a> and in this context is known as <i>London</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>141<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>It is the capital of the United Kingdom and of England by <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_convention_(political_custom)" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitutional convention (political custom)">convention</a> rather than statute. The capital of England was moved to London from <a href="/wiki/Winchester" title="Winchester">Winchester</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a> developed in the 12th and 13th centuries to become the permanent location of the <a href="/wiki/Noble_court" class="mw-redirect" title="Noble court">royal court</a>, and thus the political capital of the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-london_060_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_060-149"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>142<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Topography">Topography</h3></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg/220px-London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="151" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg/330px-London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg/440px-London_from_Primrose_Hill_May_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4388" data-file-height="3021" /></a><figcaption>London from <a href="/wiki/Primrose_Hill" title="Primrose Hill">Primrose Hill</a></figcaption></figure>

<p>Greater London encompasses a total area of 611 square miles (1,583&#160;km<sup>2</sup>) an area which had a population of 7,172,036 in 2001 and a population density of 11,760 inhabitants per square mile (4,542/km<sup>2</sup>). The extended area known as the London Metropolitan Region or the London Metropolitan Agglomeration, comprises a total area of 3,236 square miles (8,382&#160;km<sup>2</sup>) has a population of 13,709,000 and a population density of 3,900 inhabitants per square mile (1,510/km<sup>2</sup>).<sup id="cite_ref-Metrop_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Metrop-150"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Modern London stands on the <a href="/wiki/River_Thames" title="River Thames">Thames</a>, its primary geographical feature, a <a href="/wiki/Navigability" title="Navigability">navigable</a> river which crosses the city from the south-west to the east. The <a href="/wiki/Thames_Valley" title="Thames Valley">Thames Valley</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Floodplain" title="Floodplain">flood plain</a> surrounded by gently rolling hills including <a href="/wiki/Parliament_Hill,_London" title="Parliament Hill, London">Parliament Hill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Addington_Hills" title="Addington Hills">Addington Hills</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Primrose_Hill" title="Primrose Hill">Primrose Hill</a>. Historically London grew up at the <a href="/wiki/Lowest_bridging_point" title="Lowest bridging point">lowest bridging point</a> on the Thames. The Thames was once a much broader, shallower river with extensive <a href="/wiki/Marsh" title="Marsh">marshlands</a>; at high tide, its shores reached five times their present width.<sup id="cite_ref-london_065_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_065-151"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>144<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Since the <a href="/wiki/Victorian_era" title="Victorian era">Victorian era</a> the Thames has been extensively <a href="/wiki/Thames_Embankment" title="Thames Embankment">embanked</a>, and many of its London <a href="/wiki/Tributaries_of_the_River_Thames" title="Tributaries of the River Thames">tributaries</a> now flow <a href="/wiki/Subterranean_rivers_of_London" title="Subterranean rivers of London">underground</a>. The Thames is a tidal river, and London is vulnerable to flooding.<sup id="cite_ref-london_066_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_066-152"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>145<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The threat has increased over time because of a slow but continuous rise in <a href="/wiki/Tide" title="Tide">high water</a> level caused by <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a> and by the slow 'tilting' of the British Isles as a result of <a href="/wiki/Post-glacial_rebound" title="Post-glacial rebound">post-glacial rebound</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_067_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_067-153"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>146<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Climate">Climate</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_London" title="Climate of London">Climate of London</a></div>

<p>London has a temperate <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a> (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen</a>: <i>Cfb</i>). Rainfall records have been kept in the city since at least 1697, when records began at <a href="/wiki/Kew" title="Kew">Kew</a>. At Kew, the most rainfall in one month is 7.4 inches (189&#160;mm) in November 1755 and the least is 0 inches (0&#160;mm) in both December 1788 and July 1800. Mile End also had 0 inches (0&#160;mm) in April 1893.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>147<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The wettest year on record is 1903, with a total fall of 38.1 inches (969&#160;mm) and the driest is 1921, with a total fall of 12.1 inches (308&#160;mm).<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The average annual precipitation amounts to about 600mm, which is half the annual rainfall of <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Despite relatively low annual precipitation, London receives 109.6 rainy days on the 1.0mm threshold annually. London is vulnerable to <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Climate change in the United Kingdom">climate change</a>, and there is concern among <a href="/wiki/Hydrology" title="Hydrology">hydrological</a> experts that households may run out of water before 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Temperature extremes in London range from 40.2&#160;°C (104.4&#160;°F) at Heathrow on 19 July 2022 down to −17.4&#160;°C (0.7&#160;°F) at Northolt on 13 December 1981.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>151<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>152<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Records for <a href="/wiki/Atmospheric_pressure" title="Atmospheric pressure">atmospheric pressure</a> have been kept at London since 1692. The highest pressure ever reported is 1,049.8 millibars (31.00&#160;inHg) on 20 January 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>153<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Summers are generally warm, sometimes hot. London's average July high is 23.5&#160;°C (74.3&#160;°F). On average each year, London experiences 31 days above 25&#160;°C (77.0&#160;°F) and 4.2 days above 30.0&#160;°C (86.0&#160;°F). During the <a href="/wiki/2003_European_heat_wave" class="mw-redirect" title="2003 European heat wave">2003 European heat wave</a>, prolonged heat led to hundreds of heat-related deaths.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>154<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A previous spell of 15 consecutive days above 32.2&#160;°C (90.0&#160;°F) in England in 1976 also caused many heat related deaths.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>155<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A previous temperature of 37.8&#160;°C (100.0&#160;°F) in August 1911 at the Greenwich station was later disregarded as non-standard.<sup id="cite_ref-metoffice.gov.uk_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-metoffice.gov.uk-163"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>156<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Droughts can also, occasionally, be a problem, especially in summer, most recently in summer 2018, and with much drier than average conditions prevailing from May to December.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>157<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, the most consecutive days without rain was 73 days in the spring of 1893.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>158<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Winters are generally cool with little temperature variation. Heavy snow is rare but snow usually falls at least once each winter. Spring and autumn can be pleasant. As a large city, London has a considerable <a href="/wiki/Urban_heat_island" title="Urban heat island">urban heat island</a> effect,<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>159<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> making the centre of London at times 5&#160;°C (9&#160;°F) warmer than the suburbs and outskirts.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>160<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<td style="background: #FFDFC0; color:#000000;" class="notheme">9<br />(48)

<td colspan="14" style="text-align:center;font-size:95%;">Source 1: <a href="/wiki/Met_Office" title="Met Office">Met Office</a><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>161<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>162<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>163<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Royal_Netherlands_Meteorological_Institute" title="Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute">Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute</a><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>164<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>165<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

</td></tr></tbody></table>

</div>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1239543626">.mw-parser-output .reflist{margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}@media screen{.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%}}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist">

<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">

<li id="cite_note-168"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-168">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Averages are taken from Heathrow, and extremes are taken from stations across London.</span>

</li>

</ol></div></div>

<p><br />

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Areas">Areas</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_areas_of_London" title="List of areas of London">List of areas of London</a> and <a href="/wiki/London_boroughs" title="London boroughs">London boroughs</a></div>

<p>Places within London's vast urban area are identified using area names, such as <a href="/wiki/Mayfair" title="Mayfair">Mayfair</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southwark" title="Southwark">Southwark</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wembley" title="Wembley">Wembley</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Whitechapel" title="Whitechapel">Whitechapel</a>. These are either informal designations, reflect the names of villages that have been absorbed by sprawl, or are superseded administrative units such as parishes or <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_boroughs_of_the_County_of_London" title="Metropolitan boroughs of the County of London">former boroughs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>170<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:London_(44761485915).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/London_%2844761485915%29.jpg/290px-London_%2844761485915%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="290" height="172" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/London_%2844761485915%29.jpg/435px-London_%2844761485915%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/London_%2844761485915%29.jpg/580px-London_%2844761485915%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4475" data-file-height="2652" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/West_End_theatre" title="West End theatre">West End theatre</a> district in 2016</figcaption></figure>

<p>Such names have remained in use through tradition, each referring to a local area with its own distinctive character, but without official boundaries. Since 1965, Greater London has been divided into 32 <a href="/wiki/London_borough" class="mw-redirect" title="London borough">London boroughs</a> in addition to the ancient City of London.<sup id="cite_ref-london_071_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_071-179"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>171<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The City of London is the main financial district,<sup id="cite_ref-london_073_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_073-180"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>172<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a> has recently developed into a new financial and commercial hub in the <a href="/wiki/London_Docklands" title="London Docklands">Docklands</a> to the east.

</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/West_End_of_London" title="West End of London">West End</a> is London's main entertainment and shopping district, attracting tourists.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/West_(London_sub_region)" class="mw-redirect" title="West (London sub region)">West London</a> includes expensive residential areas where properties can sell for tens of millions of pounds.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The average price for properties in <a href="/wiki/Royal_Borough_of_Kensington_and_Chelsea" title="Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea">Kensington and Chelsea</a> is over £2&#160;million with a similarly high outlay in most of central London.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>175<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>176<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/East_End_of_London" title="East End of London">East End</a> is the area closest to the original <a href="/wiki/Port_of_London" title="Port of London">Port of London</a>, known for its high immigrant population, as well as for being one of the poorest areas in London.<sup id="cite_ref-East_End_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-East_End-185"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The surrounding <a href="/wiki/North_East_(London_sub_region)" class="mw-redirect" title="North East (London sub region)">East London</a> area saw much of London's early industrial development; now, <a href="/wiki/Brownfield_land" title="Brownfield land">brownfield</a> sites throughout the area are being redeveloped as part of the <a href="/wiki/Thames_Gateway" title="Thames Gateway">Thames Gateway</a> including the <a href="/wiki/London_Riverside" title="London Riverside">London Riverside</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lower_Lea_Valley" title="Lower Lea Valley">Lower Lea Valley</a>, which was developed into the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Park,_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Olympic Park, London">Olympic Park</a> for the <a href="/wiki/London_2012_Olympic_bid" class="mw-redirect" title="London 2012 Olympic bid">2012 Olympics and Paralympics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-East_End_185-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-East_End-185"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Architecture">Architecture</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_London" title="Architecture of London">Architecture of London</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_and_structures_in_London" title="List of tallest buildings and structures in London">List of tallest buildings and structures in London</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_demolished_buildings_and_structures_in_London" title="List of demolished buildings and structures in London">List of demolished buildings and structures in London</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg/260px-Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="146" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg/390px-Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg/520px-Aerial_Tower_of_London.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4687" data-file-height="2636" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Tower_of_London" title="Tower of London">Tower of London</a>, a medieval castle, dating in part to 1078</figcaption></figure>

<p>London's buildings are too diverse to be characterised by any particular architectural style, partly because of their varying ages. Many grand houses and public buildings, such as the <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery" title="National Gallery">National Gallery</a>, are constructed from <a href="/wiki/Portland_stone" title="Portland stone">Portland stone</a>. Some areas of the city, particularly those just west of the centre, are characterised by white <a href="/wiki/Stucco" title="Stucco">stucco</a> or whitewashed buildings. Few structures in central London pre-date the <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London" title="Great Fire of London">Great Fire</a> of 1666, these being a few trace <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Roman</a> remains, the <a href="/wiki/Tower_of_London" title="Tower of London">Tower of London</a> and a few scattered <a href="/wiki/Tudor_architecture" title="Tudor architecture">Tudor</a> survivors in the city. Further out is, for example, the Tudor-period <a href="/wiki/Hampton_Court_Palace" title="Hampton Court Palace">Hampton Court Palace</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>178<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Part of the varied architectural heritage are the 17th-century churches by <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Wren" title="Christopher Wren">Christopher Wren</a>, neoclassical financial institutions such as the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Exchange,_London" title="Royal Exchange, London">Royal Exchange</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a>, to the early 20th century <a href="/wiki/Old_Bailey" title="Old Bailey">Old Bailey</a> courthouse and the 1960s <a href="/wiki/Barbican_Estate" title="Barbican Estate">Barbican Estate</a>. The 1939 <a href="/wiki/Battersea_Power_Station" title="Battersea Power Station">Battersea Power Station</a> by the river in the south-west is a local landmark, while some railway termini are excellent examples of <a href="/wiki/Victorian_architecture" title="Victorian architecture">Victorian architecture</a>, most notably <a href="/wiki/St_Pancras_railway_station" title="St Pancras railway station">St. Pancras</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paddington_railway_station" class="mw-redirect" title="Paddington railway station">Paddington</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_078_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_078-187"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>179<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The density of London varies, with high employment density in the <a href="/wiki/Central_London" title="Central London">central area</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a>, high residential densities in <a href="/wiki/Inner_London" title="Inner London">inner London</a>, and lower densities in <a href="/wiki/Outer_London" title="Outer London">Outer London</a>.

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Buckingham_Palace_from_side,_London,_UK_-_Diliff.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg/220px-Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="133" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg/330px-Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg/440px-Buckingham_Palace_from_side%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg 2x" data-file-width="9000" data-file-height="5426" /></a><figcaption>The east wing public façade of <a href="/wiki/Buckingham_Palace" title="Buckingham Palace">Buckingham Palace</a> was built between 1847 and 1850; it was remodelled to its present form in 1913.</figcaption></figure>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg/220px-Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg/330px-Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg/440px-Trafalgar_Square_by_Christian_Reimer.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Trafalgar_Square" title="Trafalgar Square">Trafalgar Square</a> and its fountains, with <a href="/wiki/Nelson%27s_Column" title="Nelson&#39;s Column">Nelson's Column</a> on the right</figcaption></figure>

<p><a href="/wiki/The_Monument" class="mw-redirect" title="The Monument">The Monument</a> in the City of London provides views of the surrounding area while commemorating the <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London" title="Great Fire of London">Great Fire of London</a>, which originated nearby. <a href="/wiki/Marble_Arch" title="Marble Arch">Marble Arch</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wellington_Arch" title="Wellington Arch">Wellington Arch</a>, at the north and south ends of <a href="/wiki/Park_Lane_(road)" class="mw-redirect" title="Park Lane (road)">Park Lane</a>, respectively, have royal connections, as do the <a href="/wiki/Albert_Memorial" title="Albert Memorial">Albert Memorial</a> and <a href="/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall" title="Royal Albert Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kensington" title="Kensington">Kensington</a>. <a href="/wiki/Nelson%27s_Column" title="Nelson&#39;s Column">Nelson's Column</a> (built to commemorate <a href="/wiki/Horatio_Nelson,_1st_Viscount_Nelson" title="Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson">Admiral Horatio Nelson</a>) is a nationally recognised monument in <a href="/wiki/Trafalgar_Square" title="Trafalgar Square">Trafalgar Square</a>, one of the focal points of central London. Older buildings are mainly brick, commonly the yellow <a href="/wiki/London_stock_brick" title="London stock brick">London stock brick</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_077_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_077-188"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>In the dense areas, most of the concentration is via medium- and high-rise buildings. London's skyscrapers, such as <a href="/wiki/30_St_Mary_Axe" class="mw-redirect" title="30 St Mary Axe">30 St Mary Axe</a> (dubbed "The Gherkin"), <a href="/wiki/Tower_42" title="Tower 42">Tower 42</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Broadgate_Tower" title="Broadgate Tower">Broadgate Tower</a> and <a href="/wiki/One_Canada_Square" title="One Canada Square">One Canada Square</a>, are mostly in the two financial districts, the City of London and <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a>. High-rise development is restricted at certain sites if it would obstruct <a href="/wiki/Protected_view" title="Protected view">protected views</a> of <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul&#39;s Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a> and other historic buildings.<sup id="cite_ref-Protected_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Protected-189"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This protective policy, known as 'St Paul's Heights', has been in operation by the City of London since 1937.<sup id="cite_ref-Protected_189-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Protected-189"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Nevertheless, there are <a href="/wiki/Tall_buildings_in_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Tall buildings in London">a number of tall skyscrapers</a> in central London, including the 95-storey <a href="/wiki/Shard_London_Bridge" class="mw-redirect" title="Shard London Bridge">Shard London Bridge</a>, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of tallest buildings in the United Kingdom">tallest building in the United Kingdom</a> and Western Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>182<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Other notable modern buildings include <a href="/wiki/The_Scalpel" title="The Scalpel">The Scalpel</a>, <a href="/wiki/20_Fenchurch_Street" title="20 Fenchurch Street">20 Fenchurch Street</a> (dubbed 'The Walkie-Talkie'), the former <a href="/wiki/City_Hall,_London_(Southwark)" title="City Hall, London (Southwark)">City Hall</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southwark" title="Southwark">Southwark</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> <a href="/wiki/BBC_Broadcasting_House" class="mw-redirect" title="BBC Broadcasting House">BBC Broadcasting House</a> plus the <a href="/wiki/Postmodernism" title="Postmodernism">Postmodernist</a> <a href="/wiki/British_Library" title="British Library">British Library</a> in <a href="/wiki/Somers_Town,_London" title="Somers Town, London">Somers Town</a>/<a href="/wiki/Kings_Cross,_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Kings Cross, London">Kings Cross</a> and <a href="/wiki/No_1_Poultry" title="No 1 Poultry">No 1 Poultry</a> by <a href="/wiki/James_Stirling_(architect)" title="James Stirling (architect)">James Stirling</a>. The <a href="/wiki/BT_Tower" title="BT Tower">BT Tower</a> stands at 620 feet (189&#160;m) and has a 360 degree coloured LED screen near the top. What was formerly the <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Dome" title="Millennium Dome">Millennium Dome</a>, by the Thames to the east of Canary Wharf, is now an entertainment venue called <a href="/wiki/The_O2_Arena" title="The O2 Arena">the O<sub>2</sub> Arena</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>183<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:908px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description" title="The Houses of Parliament and Elizabeth Tower (Big Ben) on the right foreground, the London Eye on the left foreground and The Shard with Canary Wharf in the background; seen in September 2014"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_%28cropped%29.jpg/900px-Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="900" height="334" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_%28cropped%29.jpg/1350px-Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_%28cropped%29.jpg/1800px-Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7888" data-file-height="2926" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Palace_of_Westminster_from_the_dome_on_Methodist_Central_Hall_(cropped).jpg" title="File:Palace of Westminster from the dome on Methodist Central Hall (cropped).jpg"> </a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Houses_of_Parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Houses of Parliament">Houses of Parliament</a> and <a href="/wiki/Big_Ben" title="Big Ben">Elizabeth Tower</a> (Big Ben) on the right foreground, the <a href="/wiki/London_Eye" title="London Eye">London Eye</a> on the left foreground and <a href="/wiki/The_Shard" title="The Shard">The Shard</a> with <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a> in the background; seen in September 2014</div></div></div>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Natural_history">Natural history</h3></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Owl_on_a_phone_box,_Shepherd_Market.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Owl_on_a_phone_box%2C_Shepherd_Market.jpg/220px-Owl_on_a_phone_box%2C_Shepherd_Market.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Owl_on_a_phone_box%2C_Shepherd_Market.jpg/330px-Owl_on_a_phone_box%2C_Shepherd_Market.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Owl_on_a_phone_box%2C_Shepherd_Market.jpg/440px-Owl_on_a_phone_box%2C_Shepherd_Market.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4032" data-file-height="3024" /></a><figcaption>Owl decoy on top of a <a href="/wiki/Red_telephone_box" title="Red telephone box">red telephone box</a> in <a href="/wiki/Shepherd_Market" title="Shepherd Market">Shepherd Market</a> in <a href="/wiki/Mayfair" title="Mayfair">Mayfair</a> as a deterrent to pigeons; there are an estimated 3 million pigeons in London.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>

<p>The <a href="/wiki/London_Natural_History_Society" title="London Natural History Society">London Natural History Society</a> suggests that London is "one of the World's Greenest Cities" with more than 40% green space or open water. They indicate that 2000 species of flowering plant have been found growing there and that the <a href="/wiki/Tideway" title="Tideway">tidal Thames</a> supports 120 species of fish.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> They state that over 60 species of bird nest in <a href="/wiki/Central_London" title="Central London">central London</a> and that their members have recorded 47 species of butterfly, 1,173 moths and more than 270 kinds of spider around London. London's <a href="/wiki/Wetland" title="Wetland">wetland</a> areas support nationally important populations of many water birds. London has 38 <a href="/wiki/List_of_Sites_of_Special_Scientific_Interest_in_Greater_London" title="List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Greater London">Sites of Special Scientific Interest</a> (SSSIs), two <a href="/wiki/National_nature_reserve_(United_Kingdom)" title="National nature reserve (United Kingdom)">national nature reserves</a> and 76 <a href="/wiki/List_of_local_nature_reserves_in_Greater_London" title="List of local nature reserves in Greater London">local nature reserves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>186<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p><a href="/wiki/Amphibians" class="mw-redirect" title="Amphibians">Amphibians</a> are common in the capital, including <a href="/wiki/Smooth_newt" title="Smooth newt">smooth newts</a> living by the <a href="/wiki/Tate_Modern" title="Tate Modern">Tate Modern</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Common_frog" title="Common frog">common frogs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_toad" title="Common toad">common toads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palmate_newt" title="Palmate newt">palmate newts</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Great_crested_newt" class="mw-redirect" title="Great crested newt">great crested newts</a>. On the other hand, native reptiles such as <a href="/wiki/Slowworm" class="mw-redirect" title="Slowworm">slowworms</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_lizard" class="mw-redirect" title="Common lizard">common lizards</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barred_grass_snake" title="Barred grass snake">barred grass snakes</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vipera_berus" class="mw-redirect" title="Vipera berus">adders</a>, are mostly only seen in <a href="/wiki/Outer_London" title="Outer London">Outer London</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>187<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg/220px-Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="247" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg/330px-Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg/440px-Flickr_-_Duncan~_-_Fox_Trot.jpg 2x" data-file-width="967" data-file-height="1086" /></a><figcaption>A fox on Ayres Street, <a href="/wiki/Southwark" title="Southwark">Southwark</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_London" title="South London">South London</a></figcaption></figure>

<p>Among other inhabitants of London are 10,000 <a href="/wiki/Red_fox" title="Red fox">red foxes</a>, so that there are now 16 foxes for every square mile (6 per square km) of London. Other mammals found in <a href="/wiki/Greater_London" title="Greater London">Greater London</a> are <a href="/wiki/European_hedgehog" title="European hedgehog">hedgehog</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brown_rat" title="Brown rat">brown rat</a>, mice, <a href="/wiki/European_rabbit" title="European rabbit">rabbit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shrew" title="Shrew">shrew</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vole" title="Vole">vole</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Grey_squirrel" class="mw-redirect" title="Grey squirrel">grey squirrel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In wilder areas of Outer London, such as <a href="/wiki/Epping_Forest" title="Epping Forest">Epping Forest</a>, a wide variety of mammals are found, including <a href="/wiki/European_hare" title="European hare">European hare</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_badger" title="European badger">badger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Field_vole" class="mw-redirect" title="Field vole">field</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bank_vole" title="Bank vole">bank</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_water_vole" title="European water vole">water vole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wood_mouse" title="Wood mouse">wood mouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yellow-necked_mouse" title="Yellow-necked mouse">yellow-necked mouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_mole" title="European mole">mole</a>, shrew, and <a href="/wiki/Least_weasel" title="Least weasel">weasel</a>, in addition to red fox, grey squirrel and hedgehog. A dead <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_otter" title="Eurasian otter">otter</a> was found at The Highway, in <a href="/wiki/Wapping" title="Wapping">Wapping</a>, about 1&#160;mile (1.6&#160;km) from the <a href="/wiki/Tower_Bridge" title="Tower Bridge">Tower Bridge</a>, which would suggest that they have begun to move back after being absent a hundred years from the city.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Ten of England's eighteen species of bats have been recorded in Epping Forest: <a href="/wiki/Soprano_pipistrelle" title="Soprano pipistrelle">soprano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nathusius%27_pipistrelle" class="mw-redirect" title="Nathusius&#39; pipistrelle">Nathusius'</a> and <a href="/wiki/Common_pipistrelle" title="Common pipistrelle">common pipistrelles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_noctule" title="Common noctule">common noctule</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serotine" class="mw-redirect" title="Serotine">serotine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barbastelle" class="mw-redirect" title="Barbastelle">barbastelle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daubenton%27s_bat" title="Daubenton&#39;s bat">Daubenton's</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brown_long-eared_bat" title="Brown long-eared bat">brown long-eared</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natterer%27s_bat" title="Natterer&#39;s bat">Natterer's</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Leisler%27s_bat" class="mw-redirect" title="Leisler&#39;s bat">Leisler's</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Herds of <a href="/wiki/Red_deer" title="Red deer">red</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fallow_deer" title="Fallow deer">fallow deer</a> roam freely within much of <a href="/wiki/Richmond_Park" title="Richmond Park">Richmond</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bushy_Park" title="Bushy Park">Bushy Park</a>. A cull takes place each November and February to ensure numbers can be sustained.<sup id="cite_ref-Deer_cull_begins_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Deer_cull_begins-199"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>191<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Epping Forest is also known for its fallow deer, which can frequently be seen in herds to the north of the Forest. A rare population of <a href="/wiki/Melanistic" class="mw-redirect" title="Melanistic">melanistic</a>, black fallow deer is also maintained at the Deer Sanctuary near <a href="/wiki/Theydon_Bois" title="Theydon Bois">Theydon Bois</a>. <a href="/wiki/Reeve%27s_muntjac" class="mw-redirect" title="Reeve&#39;s muntjac">Muntjac deer</a> are also found in the forest. While Londoners are accustomed to wildlife such as birds and foxes sharing the city, more recently urban deer have started becoming a regular feature, and whole herds of fallow deer come into residential areas at night to take advantage of London's green spaces.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Demography">Demography</h2></div>

<th>100.0

</th></tr></tbody></table>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Greater_London_population_density_map,_2011_census.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Greater_London_population_density_map%2C_2011_census.png/290px-Greater_London_population_density_map%2C_2011_census.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="237" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Greater_London_population_density_map%2C_2011_census.png/435px-Greater_London_population_density_map%2C_2011_census.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Greater_London_population_density_map%2C_2011_census.png/580px-Greater_London_population_density_map%2C_2011_census.png 2x" data-file-width="3896" data-file-height="3178" /></a><figcaption>Population density map</figcaption></figure>

<p>London's continuous urban area extends beyond Greater London and numbered 9,787,426 people in 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-urbanpopulation_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-urbanpopulation-4"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while its wider <a href="/wiki/London_metropolitan_area" title="London metropolitan area">metropolitan area</a> had a population of 12–14&#160;million, depending on the definition used.<sup id="cite_ref-metro_area_1_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-metro_area_1-202"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a>, London is the second <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Europe" title="List of metropolitan areas in Europe">most populous</a> metropolitan area in Europe. A net 726,000&#160;immigrants arrived there in the period 1991–2001.<sup id="cite_ref-Immigration_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Immigration-203"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>The region covers 610 square miles (1,579&#160;km<sup>2</sup>), giving a population density of 13,410 inhabitants per square mile (5,177/km<sup>2</sup>)<sup id="cite_ref-Metrop_150-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Metrop-150"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> more than ten times that of any other <a href="/wiki/ITL_(UK)" class="mw-redirect" title="ITL (UK)">British region</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_087_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_087-204"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In population terms, London is the 19th <a href="/wiki/World%27s_largest_cities" class="mw-redirect" title="World&#39;s largest cities">largest city</a> and the 18th <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of metropolitan areas by population">largest metropolitan region</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Billionaires_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Billionaires-205"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>In tenure, 23.1% socially rent within London, 46.8% either own their house outright or with a mortgage or loan and 30% privately rent at the 2021 census.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Many Londoner's work from home, 42.9% did so at the 2021 census while 20.6% drive a car to work. The biggest decrease in method of transportation was seen within those who take the train and underground, declining from 22.6% in 2011 to 9.6% in 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In qualifications, 46.7% of London had census classified Level 4 qualifications or higher, which is predominately university degrees. 16.2% had no qualifications at all.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Age_structure_and_median_age">Age structure and median age</h3></div>

<p>London's median age is one of the youngest regions in the UK. It was recorded in 2018 that London's residents were 36.5&#160;years old, which was younger than the UK median of 40.3.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-209"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Children younger than 14 constituted 20.6% of the population in Outer London in 2018, and 18% in Inner London. The 15–24 age group was 11.1% in Outer and 10.2% in Inner London, those aged 25–44&#160;years 30.6% in Outer London and 39.7% in Inner London, those aged 45–64&#160;years 24% and 20.7% in Outer and Inner London respectively. Those aged 65 and over are 13.6% in Outer London, but only 9.3% in Inner London.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_209-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-209"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Country_of_birth">Country of birth</h3></div>

<p>The 2021 census recorded that 3,575,739 people or 40.6% of London's population were <a href="/wiki/Foreign-born_population_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Foreign-born population of the United Kingdom">foreign-born</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Census2021_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2021-210"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> making it among the cities with the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_born#Cities_with_largest_foreign_born_populations" title="Foreign born">largest immigrant population</a> in terms of absolute numbers and a growth of roughly 3 million since 1971 when the foreign born population was 668,373.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>203<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 13% of the total population were Asian born (32.1% of the total foreign born population), 7.1% are African born (17.5%), 15.5% are Other European born (38.2%), and 4.2% were born in the Americas and Caribbean (10.3%).<sup id="cite_ref-:3_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-212"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The 5 largest single countries of origin were respectively India, Romania, Poland, Bangladesh and Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_212-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-212"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>About 56.8% of children born in London in 2021 were born to a mother who was born abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-213"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This trend has been increasing in the past two decades when foreign born mothers made up 43.3% of births in 2001 in London, becoming the majority in the middle of the 2000s by 2006 comprising 52.5%.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_213-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-213"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>A large degree of the foreign born population who were present at the 2021 census had arrived relatively recently. Of the total population, those that arrived between the years of 2011 and 2021 account for 16.6% of London.<sup id="cite_ref-:6_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:6-214"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Those who arrived between 2001 and 2010 are 10.4%, between 1991 and 2001, 5.7%, and prior to 1990, 7.3%.<sup id="cite_ref-:6_214-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:6-214"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_London" title="Ethnic groups in London">Ethnic groups in London</a></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader" style="text-align:center">Maps of Greater London showing percentage distribution of selected ethnic groups according to the 2021 Census</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:White_London_2021.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="White" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/White_London_2021.png/200px-White_London_2021.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="154" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/White_London_2021.png/300px-White_London_2021.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/White_London_2021.png/400px-White_London_2021.png 2x" data-file-width="4167" data-file-height="3205" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/White_people_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="White people in the United Kingdom">White</a> (53.8%)</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Asian_London_2021.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Asian" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Asian_London_2021.png/200px-Asian_London_2021.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="155" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Asian_London_2021.png/300px-Asian_London_2021.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Asian_London_2021.png/400px-Asian_London_2021.png 2x" data-file-width="4134" data-file-height="3212" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/British_Asian" class="mw-redirect" title="British Asian">Asian</a> (20.8%)</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Black_London_2021.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Black" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Black_London_2021.png/200px-Black_London_2021.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Black_London_2021.png/300px-Black_London_2021.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Black_London_2021.png/400px-Black_London_2021.png 2x" data-file-width="4803" data-file-height="3597" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Black_British_people" title="Black British people">Black</a> (13.5%)</div></div></div></div></div>

<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics" title="Office for National Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a>, based on the 2021 census, 53.8% of the 8,173,941 inhabitants of London were <a href="/wiki/White_people" title="White people">White</a>, with 36.8% <a href="/wiki/White_British" title="White British">White British</a>, 1.8% <a href="/wiki/Irish_migration_to_Great_Britain" class="mw-redirect" title="Irish migration to Great Britain">White Irish</a>, 0.1% <a href="/wiki/Gypsy_(term)" class="mw-redirect" title="Gypsy (term)">Gypsy</a>/<a href="/wiki/Irish_traveller" class="mw-redirect" title="Irish traveller">Irish Traveller</a>, 0.4 Roma and 14.7% classified as <a href="/wiki/Other_White" title="Other White">Other White</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:5_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-215"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Meanwhile, 22.2% of Londoners were of <a href="/wiki/British_Asian" class="mw-redirect" title="British Asian">Asian</a> or mixed-Asian descent, with 20.8% being of full Asian descents and 1.4% being of mixed-Asian heritage. <a href="/wiki/British_Indian" class="mw-redirect" title="British Indian">Indians</a> accounted for 7.5% of the population, followed by <a href="/wiki/British_Bangladeshi" class="mw-redirect" title="British Bangladeshi">Bangladeshis</a> and <a href="/wiki/British_Pakistanis" title="British Pakistanis">Pakistanis</a> at 3.7% and 3.3% respectively. <a href="/wiki/British_Chinese" title="British Chinese">Chinese</a> people accounted for 1.7%, and <a href="/wiki/British_Arabs" title="British Arabs">Arabs</a> for 1.6%. A further 4.6% were classified as "Other Asian".<sup id="cite_ref-:5_215-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-215"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 15.9% of London's population were of <a href="/wiki/Black_British" class="mw-redirect" title="Black British">Black</a> or mixed-Black descent. 13.5% were of full Black descent, with persons of mixed-Black heritage comprising 2.4%. <a href="/wiki/Black_British" class="mw-redirect" title="Black British">Black Africans</a> accounted for 7.9% of London's population; 3.9% identified as <a href="/wiki/British_African-Caribbean_community" class="mw-redirect" title="British African-Caribbean community">Black Caribbean</a>, and 1.7% as "Other Black". 5.7% were of <a href="/wiki/Mixed_(United_Kingdom_ethnicity_category)" title="Mixed (United Kingdom ethnicity category)">mixed race</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:5_215-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-215"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This ethnic structure has changed considerably since the 1960s. Estimates for 1961 put the total non-White ethnic minority population at 179,109 comprising 2.3% of the population at the time,<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> having risen since then to 1,346,119 and 20.2% in 1991<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and 4,068,553 and 46.2% in 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-:7_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:7-219"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Of those of a White British background, estimates for 1971 put the population at 6,500,000 and 87% of the total population,<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> of since fell to 3,239,281 and 36.8% in 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-:7_219-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:7-219"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>As of 2021, the majority of London's school pupils come from ethnic minority backgrounds. 23.9% were White British, 14% Other White, 23.2% Asian, 17.9% Black, 11.3% Mixed, 6.3% Other and 2.3% unclassified.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Altogether at the 2021 census, of London's 1,695,741 population aged 0 to 15, 42% were White in total, splitting it down into 30.9% who were White British, 0.5% Irish, 10.6% Other White, 23% Asian, 16.4% Black, 12% Mixed and 6.6% another ethnic group.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Languages">Languages</h3></div>

<p>In January 2005, a survey of London's ethnic and religious diversity claimed that more than 300 languages were spoken in London and more than 50 non-indigenous communities had populations of more than 10,000.<sup id="cite_ref-london_090_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_090-223"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>215<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> At the 2021 census, 78.4% of Londoners spoke English as their first language.<sup id="cite_ref-:8_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:8-224"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The 5 biggest languages outside of English were Romanian, Spanish, Polish, Bengali, and Portuguese.<sup id="cite_ref-:8_224-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:8-224"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Religion">Religion</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_London" title="Religion in London">Religion in London</a></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_churches_in_London" title="List of churches in London">List of churches in London</a></div>

<div class="thumbcaption">

<p>Religion in London (2021)<sup id="cite_ref-census2021_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census2021-225"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:DodgerBlue; color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> (40.66%)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:honeydew; color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">No Religion</a> (27.05%)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Green; color:white;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> (14.99%)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:darkorange; color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> (5.15%)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:turquoise; color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a> (1.65%)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:yellow; color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a> (1.64%)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:goldenrod;
