color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> (0.99%)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:deeppink; color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;Other Religions (0.88%)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:lightgrey; color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;Religion not Stated (7.00%)</div>

</div>

</div></div>

<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/2021_United_Kingdom_census" title="2021 United Kingdom census">2021 Census</a>, the largest religious groupings were <a href="/wiki/British_Christianity" class="mw-redirect" title="British Christianity">Christians</a> (40.66%), followed by those of no religion (20.7%), <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_London" title="Islam in London">Muslims</a> (15%), no response (8.5%), <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Hinduism in the United Kingdom">Hindus</a> (5.15%), Jews (1.65%), <a href="/wiki/Sikhism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Sikhism in the United Kingdom">Sikhs</a> (1.64%), <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Buddhism in the United Kingdom">Buddhists</a> (1.0%) and other (0.8%).<sup id="cite_ref-census2021_225-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census2021-225"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>London has traditionally been <a href="/wiki/Christian" class="mw-redirect" title="Christian">Christian</a>, and has a <a href="/wiki/List_of_churches_in_London" title="List of churches in London">large number of churches</a>, particularly in the City of London. The well-known <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul&#39;s Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a> in the City and <a href="/wiki/Southwark_Cathedral" title="Southwark Cathedral">Southwark Cathedral</a> south of the river are <a href="/wiki/Anglicanism" title="Anglicanism">Anglican</a> administrative centres,<sup id="cite_ref-london_096_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_096-227"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>219<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/Archbishop_of_Canterbury" title="Archbishop of Canterbury">Archbishop of Canterbury</a>, principal bishop of the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_England" title="Church of England">Church of England</a> and worldwide <a href="/wiki/Anglican_Communion" title="Anglican Communion">Anglican Communion</a>, has his main residence at <a href="/wiki/Lambeth_Palace" title="Lambeth Palace">Lambeth Palace</a> in the <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Lambeth" title="London Borough of Lambeth">London Borough of Lambeth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_097_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_097-228"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>220<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Important national and royal ceremonies are shared between <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul&#39;s Cathedral">St Paul's</a> and <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_098_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_098-229"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Abbey is not to be confused with nearby <a href="/wiki/Westminster_Cathedral" title="Westminster Cathedral">Westminster Cathedral</a>, the largest <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> cathedral in <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales" title="England and Wales">England and Wales</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_099_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_099-230"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Despite the prevalence of Anglican churches, observance is low within the denomination. Anglican Church attendance continues a long, steady decline, according to Church of England statistics.<sup id="cite_ref-london_100_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_100-231"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Notable mosques include the <a href="/wiki/East_London_Mosque" title="East London Mosque">East London Mosque</a> in Tower Hamlets, which is allowed to give the Islamic call to prayer through loudspeakers, the <a href="/wiki/London_Central_Mosque" title="London Central Mosque">London Central Mosque</a> on the edge of <a href="/wiki/Regent%27s_Park" title="Regent&#39;s Park">Regent's Park</a><sup id="cite_ref-london_101_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_101-232"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Baitul_Futuh" class="mw-redirect" title="Baitul Futuh">Baitul Futuh</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya_Muslim_Community" class="mw-redirect" title="Ahmadiyya Muslim Community">Ahmadiyya Muslim Community</a>. After the oil boom, increasing numbers of wealthy <a href="/wiki/Middle-East" class="mw-redirect" title="Middle-East">Middle-Eastern</a> Arab Muslims based themselves around <a href="/wiki/Mayfair" title="Mayfair">Mayfair</a>, Kensington and <a href="/wiki/Knightsbridge" title="Knightsbridge">Knightsbridge</a> in West London.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>226<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-london_102_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_102-235"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are large <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengali Muslim">Bengali Muslim</a> communities in the eastern boroughs of <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Tower_Hamlets" title="London Borough of Tower Hamlets">Tower Hamlets</a> and <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Newham" title="London Borough of Newham">Newham</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Large Hindu communities are found in the north-western boroughs of <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Harrow" title="London Borough of Harrow">Harrow</a> and <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Brent" title="London Borough of Brent">Brent</a>, the latter hosting what was until 2006<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Europe's largest <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neasden_Temple" class="mw-redirect" title="Neasden Temple">Neasden Temple</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_103_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_103-238"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London is home to 44 Hindu temples, including the <a href="/wiki/BAPS_Shri_Swaminarayan_Mandir_London" title="BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir London">BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir London</a>. There are Sikh communities in East and West London, particularly in Southall, home to one of the largest Sikh populations and the largest Sikh temple outside India.<sup id="cite_ref-london_104_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_104-239"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>The majority of <a href="/wiki/British_Jews" title="British Jews">British Jews</a> live in London, with notable Jewish communities in <a href="/wiki/Stamford_Hill" title="Stamford Hill">Stamford Hill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanmore" title="Stanmore">Stanmore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Golders_Green" title="Golders Green">Golders Green</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finchley" title="Finchley">Finchley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hampstead" title="Hampstead">Hampstead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hendon" title="Hendon">Hendon</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Edgware" title="Edgware">Edgware</a>, all in <a href="/wiki/North_London" title="North London">North London</a>. <a href="/wiki/Bevis_Marks_Synagogue" title="Bevis Marks Synagogue">Bevis Marks Synagogue</a> in the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a> is affiliated to London's historic <a href="/wiki/Sephardic" class="mw-redirect" title="Sephardic">Sephardic</a> Jewish community. It is the only synagogue in Europe to have held regular services continually for over 300&#160;years. <a href="/wiki/Stanmore_and_Canons_Park_Synagogue" title="Stanmore and Canons Park Synagogue">Stanmore and Canons Park Synagogue</a> has the largest membership of any Orthodox synagogue in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-london_106_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_106-240"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/London_Jewish_Forum" title="London Jewish Forum">London Jewish Forum</a> was set up in 2006 in response to the growing significance of devolved London Government.<sup id="cite_ref-london_107_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_107-241"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Accents">Accents</h3></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:St_Mary-le-Bow_-_geograph.org.uk_-_3756403.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/St_Mary-le-Bow_-_geograph.org.uk_-_3756403.jpg/170px-St_Mary-le-Bow_-_geograph.org.uk_-_3756403.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="300" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/St_Mary-le-Bow_-_geograph.org.uk_-_3756403.jpg/255px-St_Mary-le-Bow_-_geograph.org.uk_-_3756403.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/St_Mary-le-Bow_-_geograph.org.uk_-_3756403.jpg/340px-St_Mary-le-Bow_-_geograph.org.uk_-_3756403.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1165" data-file-height="2055" /></a><figcaption>Traditionally, anyone born within earshot of the bells of <a href="/wiki/St_Mary-le-Bow" title="St Mary-le-Bow">St Mary-le-Bow</a> church was considered to be a true <a href="/wiki/Cockney" title="Cockney">Cockney</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>

<p><a href="/wiki/Cockney" title="Cockney">Cockney</a> is an accent heard across London, mainly spoken by <a href="/wiki/Working_class" title="Working class">working-class</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lower_middle_class" title="Lower middle class">lower-middle-class</a> Londoners. It is mainly attributed to the East End and wider East London, having originated there in the 18th century, although it has been suggested that the Cockney style of speech is much older.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some features of Cockney include <a href="/wiki/Th-fronting" title="Th-fronting"><i>Th</i>-fronting</a> (pronouncing "th" as "f"), "th" inside a word is pronounced with a "v", <a href="/wiki/H-dropping" title="H-dropping"><i>H</i>-dropping</a>, and, like most English accents, a Cockney accent <a href="/wiki/Rhoticity_in_English" title="Rhoticity in English">drops the "r"</a> after a vowel.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> John Camden Hotten, in his <i>Slang Dictionary</i> of 1859, makes reference to Cockney "use of a peculiar slang language" (<a href="/wiki/Rhyming_slang" title="Rhyming slang">Cockney rhyming slang</a>) when describing the <a href="/wiki/Costermonger" title="Costermonger">costermongers</a> of the East End. Since the start of the 21st century the extreme form of the Cockney dialect is less common in parts of the East End itself, with modern strongholds including other parts of London and suburbs in the <a href="/wiki/Home_counties" title="Home counties">home counties</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This is particularly pronounced in areas like Romford (in the London Borough of Havering) and <a href="/wiki/Southend-on-Sea" title="Southend-on-Sea">Southend</a> (in Essex), which have received significant inflows of older East End residents in recent decades.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p><a href="/wiki/Estuary_English" title="Estuary English">Estuary English</a> is an intermediate accent between Cockney and <a href="/wiki/Received_Pronunciation" title="Received Pronunciation">Received Pronunciation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is widely spoken by people of all classes.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p><a href="/wiki/Multicultural_London_English" title="Multicultural London English">Multicultural London English</a> (MLE) is a <a href="/wiki/Multiethnolect" title="Multiethnolect">multiethnolect</a> becoming increasingly common in multicultural areas amongst young, working-class people from diverse backgrounds. It is a fusion of an array of ethnic accents, in particular Afro-Caribbean and South Asian, with a significant Cockney influence.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p><a href="/wiki/Received_Pronunciation" title="Received Pronunciation">Received Pronunciation</a> (RP) is the accent traditionally regarded as the standard for <a href="/wiki/British_English" title="British English">British English</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It has no specific geographical correlate,<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> although it is also traditionally defined as the standard speech used in London and south-eastern England.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is mainly spoken by <a href="/wiki/Upper_class" title="Upper class">upper-class</a> and <a href="/wiki/Upper_middle_class" title="Upper middle class">upper-middle class</a> Londoners.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Standard Southern British English (SSBE) has been considered as an evolution of RP that is now common and widely spoken in London and the south-east of England by a wide variety of people, but is distinct from Estuary English and MLE.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Economy">Economy</h2></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_London" title="Economy of London">Economy of London</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:City_of_London_skyscrapers_HDR_-_2023-03-18.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/City_of_London_skyscrapers_HDR_-_2023-03-18.jpg/220px-City_of_London_skyscrapers_HDR_-_2023-03-18.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/City_of_London_skyscrapers_HDR_-_2023-03-18.jpg/330px-City_of_London_skyscrapers_HDR_-_2023-03-18.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/City_of_London_skyscrapers_HDR_-_2023-03-18.jpg/440px-City_of_London_skyscrapers_HDR_-_2023-03-18.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4438" data-file-height="2959" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a>, one of the largest <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial centres</a> in the world</figcaption></figure>

<p>London's <a href="/wiki/Gross_regional_product" class="mw-redirect" title="Gross regional product">gross regional product</a> in 2019 was £503&#160;billion, around a quarter of <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Economy of the United Kingdom">UK GDP</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London has five major business districts: the city, Westminster, Canary Wharf, Camden &amp; Islington, and Lambeth &amp; Southwark. One way to get an idea of their relative importance is to look at relative amounts of office space: Greater London had 27&#160;million&#160;m<sup>2</sup> of office space in 2001, and the City contains the most space, with 8&#160;million&#160;m<sup>2</sup> of office space. London has some of the highest real estate prices in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="City_of_London">City of London</h3></div>

<p>London's finance industry is based in the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a>, the two major <a href="/wiki/Central_business_district" title="Central business district">business districts</a>. London took over as a major financial centre shortly after 1795 when the Dutch Republic collapsed before the Napoleonic armies. This caused many bankers established in <a href="/wiki/Amsterdam" title="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a> (e.g. Hope, Baring I'm), to move to London. Also, London's market-centred system (as opposed to the bank-centred one in Amsterdam) grew more dominant in the 18th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Finance_Hub_81-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Finance_Hub-81"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The London financial elite was strengthened by a strong Jewish community from all over Europe capable of mastering the most sophisticated financial tools of the time.<sup id="cite_ref-auto2_85-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-85"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This economic strength of the city was attributed to its diversity.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Paternoster_Square.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Paternoster_Square.jpg/220px-Paternoster_Square.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Paternoster_Square.jpg/330px-Paternoster_Square.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Paternoster_Square.jpg/440px-Paternoster_Square.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange" title="London Stock Exchange">London Stock Exchange</a> at <a href="/wiki/Paternoster_Square" title="Paternoster Square">Paternoster Square</a> and <a href="/wiki/Temple_Bar,_London" title="Temple Bar, London">Temple Bar</a></figcaption></figure>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:London.bankofengland.arp.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/London.bankofengland.arp.jpg/220px-London.bankofengland.arp.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="179" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/London.bankofengland.arp.jpg/330px-London.bankofengland.arp.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/London.bankofengland.arp.jpg/440px-London.bankofengland.arp.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2047" data-file-height="1669" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a>, established in 1694, is the model on which most modern central banks are based.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>

<p>By the mid-19th century, London was the leading financial centre, and at the end of the century over half the world's trade was financed in British currency.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=London&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, London ranks second in the world rankings on the <a href="/wiki/Global_Financial_Centres_Index" title="Global Financial Centres Index">Global Financial Centres Index</a> (GFCI),<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and it ranked second in A.T. Kearney's 2018 Global Cities Index.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>London's largest industry is finance, and its <a href="/wiki/Financial_export" class="mw-redirect" title="Financial export">financial exports</a> make it a large contributor to the UK's <a href="/wiki/Balance_of_payments" title="Balance of payments">balance of payments</a>. Notwithstanding a post-<a href="/wiki/Brexit" title="Brexit">Brexit</a> exodus of stock listings from the <a href="/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange" title="London Stock Exchange">London Stock Exchange</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-LSEExodusToNewYork_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LSEExodusToNewYork-24"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-LSEExodus_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LSEExodus-25"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London is still one of Europe's most economically powerful cities,<sup id="cite_ref-London.gov.uk_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-London.gov.uk-26"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and it remains one of the major financial centres of the world. It is the world's biggest currency trading centre, accounting for some 37% of the $5.1&#160;trillion average daily volume, according to the BIS.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Over 85% (3.2&#160;million) of the employed population of greater London works in the services industries. Because of its prominent global role, London's economy had been affected by the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008" class="mw-redirect" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2008">financial crisis of 2007–2008</a>. However, by 2010 the city had recovered, put in place new regulatory powers, proceeded to regain lost ground and re-established London's economic dominance.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Along with <a href="/wiki/Professional_services" title="Professional services">professional services</a> headquarters, the City of London is home to the <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a>, London Stock Exchange, and <a href="/wiki/Lloyd%27s_of_London" title="Lloyd&#39;s of London">Lloyd's of London</a> insurance market.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Founded in 1690, <a href="/wiki/Barclays" title="Barclays">Barclays</a>, whose <a href="/wiki/Barclays_Bank,_Enfield" title="Barclays Bank, Enfield">branch in Enfield</a>, north London installed the first <a href="/wiki/Automated_teller_machine" class="mw-redirect" title="Automated teller machine">cash machine</a> (ATM) in 1967, is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_oldest_banks_in_continuous_operation" title="List of oldest banks in continuous operation">oldest banks in continuous operation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Over half the UK's top 100 listed companies (the <a href="/wiki/FTSE_100" class="mw-redirect" title="FTSE 100">FTSE 100</a>) and over 100 of Europe's 500 largest companies have their headquarters in central London. Over 70% of the FTSE 100 are within London's metropolitan area, and 75% of <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">Fortune 500</a> companies have offices in London.<sup id="cite_ref-london_113_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_113-267"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In a 1992 report commissioned by the London Stock Exchange, Sir <a href="/wiki/Adrian_Cadbury" title="Adrian Cadbury">Adrian Cadbury</a>, chairman of his family's confectionery company <a href="/wiki/Cadbury" title="Cadbury">Cadbury</a>, produced the <a href="/wiki/Cadbury_Report" title="Cadbury Report">Cadbury Report</a>, a code of best practice which served as a basis for reform of <a href="/wiki/Corporate_governance" title="Corporate governance">corporate governance</a> around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Media_and_technology">Media and technology</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_in_London" title="Media in London">Media in London</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Broadcasting_House_20160816.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Broadcasting_House_20160816.jpg/170px-Broadcasting_House_20160816.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="255" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Broadcasting_House_20160816.jpg/255px-Broadcasting_House_20160816.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Broadcasting_House_20160816.jpg/340px-Broadcasting_House_20160816.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="5184" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Broadcasting_House" title="Broadcasting House">Broadcasting House</a>, headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a></figcaption></figure>

<p>Media companies are concentrated in London, and the media distribution industry is London's second most competitive sector.<sup id="cite_ref-london_114_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_114-269"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a>, the world's oldest national broadcaster, is a significant employer, while other broadcasters, including <a href="/wiki/ITV_(TV_network)" title="ITV (TV network)">ITV</a>, <a href="/wiki/Channel_4" title="Channel 4">Channel 4</a>, <a href="/wiki/Channel_5_(UK)" class="mw-redirect" title="Channel 5 (UK)">Channel 5</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sky_UK" title="Sky UK">Sky</a>, also have headquarters around the city. Many <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of newspapers in the United Kingdom">national newspapers</a>, including <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i>, founded in 1785, are edited in London; the term <a href="/wiki/Fleet_Street" title="Fleet Street">Fleet Street</a> (where most national newspapers operated) remains a <a href="/wiki/Metonym" class="mw-redirect" title="Metonym">metonym</a> for the British national press.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The communications company <a href="/wiki/WPP_plc" title="WPP plc">WPP</a> is the world's largest advertising agency.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>A large number of technology companies are based in London, notably in <a href="/wiki/East_London_Tech_City" title="East London Tech City">East London Tech City</a>, also known as Silicon Roundabout. In 2014 the city was among the first to receive a <a href="/wiki/GeoTLD" class="mw-redirect" title="GeoTLD">geoTLD</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In February 2014 London was ranked as the European City of the Future in the 2014/15 list by <i><a href="/wiki/FDi_Intelligence" title="FDi Intelligence">fDi Intelligence</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A museum in <a href="/wiki/Bletchley_Park" title="Bletchley Park">Bletchley Park</a>, where <a href="/wiki/Alan_Turing" title="Alan Turing">Alan Turing</a> was based during World War II, is in <a href="/wiki/Bletchley" title="Bletchley">Bletchley</a>, 40 miles (64&#160;km) north of central London, as is <a href="/wiki/The_National_Museum_of_Computing" title="The National Museum of Computing">The National Museum of Computing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>The gas and electricity distribution networks that manage and operate the towers, cables and pressure systems that deliver energy to consumers across the city are managed by <a href="/wiki/National_Grid_plc" title="National Grid plc">National Grid plc</a>, <a href="/wiki/SGN_(company)" title="SGN (company)">SGN</a><sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/UK_Power_Networks" title="UK Power Networks">UK Power Networks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Tourism">Tourism</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_London" title="Tourism in London">Tourism in London</a></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:British_Museum_from_NE_2_(cropped).JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG/200px-British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="124" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG/300px-British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG/400px-British_Museum_from_NE_2_%28cropped%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1593" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/British_Museum" title="British Museum">British Museum</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional,_Londres,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-07,_DD_036.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG/200px-Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="106" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG/300px-Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG/400px-Galer%C3%ADa_Nacional%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-07%2C_DD_036.JPG 2x" data-file-width="5023" data-file-height="2662" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery" title="National Gallery">National Gallery</a></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>London is one of the leading tourist destinations in the world. It is also the top city in the world by visitor cross-border spending, estimated at US$20.23&#160;billion in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Tourism is one of London's prime industries, employing 700,000 full-time workers in 2016, and contributes £36&#160;billion a year to the economy.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The city accounts for 54% of all inbound visitor spending in the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>In 2015, the top ten most-visited attractions in the UK were all in London (shown with visits per venue):<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<ol><li><a href="/wiki/British_Museum" title="British Museum">British Museum</a>: 6,820,686</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/National_Gallery" title="National Gallery">National Gallery</a>: 5,908,254</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_London" title="Natural History Museum, London">Natural History Museum</a> (South Kensington): 5,284,023</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Southbank_Centre" title="Southbank Centre">Southbank Centre</a>: 5,102,883</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Tate_Modern" title="Tate Modern">Tate Modern</a>: 4,712,581</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Victoria_and_Albert_Museum" title="Victoria and Albert Museum">Victoria and Albert Museum</a> (South Kensington): 3,432,325</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Science_Museum,_London" title="Science Museum, London">Science Museum</a>: 3,356,212</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Somerset_House" title="Somerset House">Somerset House</a>: 3,235,104</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Tower_of_London" title="Tower of London">Tower of London</a>: 2,785,249</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/National_Portrait_Gallery,_London" title="National Portrait Gallery, London">National Portrait Gallery</a>: 2,145,486</li></ol>

<p>The number of hotel rooms in London in 2023 stood at 155,700 and is expected to grow to 183,600 rooms, the most of any city outside China.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Luxury hotels in London include <a href="/wiki/Savoy_Hotel" title="Savoy Hotel">the Savoy</a> (opened in 1889), <a href="/wiki/Claridge%27s" title="Claridge&#39;s">Claridge's</a> (opened in 1812 and rebuilt in 1898), <a href="/wiki/The_Ritz_Hotel,_London" title="The Ritz Hotel, London">the Ritz</a> (opened in 1906) and <a href="/wiki/The_Dorchester" title="The Dorchester">the Dorchester</a> (opened in 1931), while budget hotel chains include <a href="/wiki/Premier_Inn" title="Premier Inn">Premier Inn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Travelodge" title="Travelodge">Travelodge</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Transport">Transport</h2></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_London" title="Transport in London">Transport in London</a> and <a href="/wiki/Infrastructure_in_London" title="Infrastructure in London">Infrastructure in London</a></div>

<p>Transport is one of the four main areas of policy administered by the <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_London" title="Mayor of London">Mayor of London</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-london_121_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_121-283"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> but the mayor's financial control does not extend to the longer-distance rail network that enters London. In 2007, the Mayor of London assumed responsibility for some local lines, which now form the <a href="/wiki/London_Overground" title="London Overground">London Overground</a> network, adding to the existing responsibility for the London Underground, trams and buses. The public transport network is administered by <a href="/wiki/Transport_for_London" title="Transport for London">Transport for London</a> (TfL).<sup id="cite_ref-london_goverance_118-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_goverance-118"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>The lines that formed the London Underground, as well as trams and buses, became part of an integrated transport system in 1933 when the <a href="/wiki/London_Passenger_Transport_Board" title="London Passenger Transport Board">London Passenger Transport Board</a> or <i><a href="/wiki/London_Transport_(brand)" title="London Transport (brand)">London Transport</a></i> was created. Transport for London is now the statutory corporation responsible for most aspects of the transport system in Greater London, and is run by a board and a commissioner appointed by the Mayor of London.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Aviation">Aviation</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Airports_of_London" title="Airports of London">Airports of London</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg/220px-Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg/330px-Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg/440px-Heathrow_Terminal_5C_Iwelumo-1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="797" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Heathrow_Airport" title="Heathrow Airport">Heathrow Airport</a> is the busiest airport in Europe as well as the second busiest in the world for international passenger traffic (<a href="/wiki/Heathrow_Terminal_5" title="Heathrow Terminal 5">Terminal 5</a>C is pictured).</figcaption></figure>

<p>London is a major international air transport hub with the <a href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_city_airport_systems_by_passenger_traffic" class="mw-redirect" title="World&#39;s busiest city airport systems by passenger traffic">busiest city airspace</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Busiest_skies_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Busiest_skies-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Eight airports use the word <i>London</i> in their name, but most traffic passes through six of these. Additionally, <a href="/wiki/Airports_of_London" title="Airports of London">various other airports</a> also serve London, catering primarily to <a href="/wiki/General_aviation" title="General aviation">general aviation</a> flights.

</p>

<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Heathrow_Airport" title="Heathrow Airport">Heathrow Airport</a>, in <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Hillingdon" title="London Borough of Hillingdon">Hillingdon</a>, West London, was for many years the <a href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airport" class="mw-redirect" title="World&#39;s busiest airport">busiest airport</a> in the world for international traffic, and is the major hub of the nation's flag carrier, <a href="/wiki/British_Airways" title="British Airways">British Airways</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-london_135_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_135-285"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In March 2008 its fifth terminal was opened.<sup id="cite_ref-london_137_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_137-286"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Gatwick_Airport" title="Gatwick Airport">Gatwick Airport</a>, south of London in <a href="/wiki/West_Sussex" title="West Sussex">West Sussex</a>, handles flights to more destinations than any other UK airport and is the main base of <a href="/wiki/EasyJet" title="EasyJet">easyJet</a>, the UK's largest airline by number of passengers.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/London_Stansted_Airport" title="London Stansted Airport">London Stansted Airport</a>, north-east of London in <a href="/wiki/Essex" title="Essex">Essex</a>, has flights that serve the greatest number of European destinations of any UK airport and is the main base of <a href="/wiki/Ryanair" title="Ryanair">Ryanair</a>, the world's largest international airline by number of international passengers.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>280<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Luton_Airport" title="Luton Airport">Luton Airport</a>, to the north of London in <a href="/wiki/Bedfordshire" title="Bedfordshire">Bedfordshire</a>, is used by several budget airlines (especially easyJet and <a href="/wiki/Wizz_Air" title="Wizz Air">Wizz Air</a>) for short-haul flights.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/London_City_Airport" title="London City Airport">London City Airport</a>, the most central airport and the one with the shortest runway, in <a href="/wiki/London_Borough_of_Newham" title="London Borough of Newham">Newham</a>, East London, is focused on business travellers, with a mixture of full-service short-haul scheduled flights and considerable <a href="/wiki/Business_jet" title="Business jet">business jet</a> traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/London_Southend_Airport" title="London Southend Airport">London Southend Airport</a>, east of London in Essex, is a smaller, regional airport that caters for short-haul flights on a limited, though growing, number of airlines.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2017, international passengers made up over 95% of the total at Southend, the highest proportion of any London airport.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></li></ul>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Rail">Rail</h3></div>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Underground_and_DLR">Underground and DLR</h4></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:220px;max-width:220px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:218px;max-width:218px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg/216px-Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg" decoding="async" width="216" height="151" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg/324px-Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg/432px-Baker_Street_tube_station_MMB_19_S_Stock.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4452" data-file-height="3102" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London Underground</a>, opened in January 1863, is the world's oldest and third-longest <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">rapid transit</a> system</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:218px;max-width:218px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Monument_Underground_Station_-_geograph.org.uk_-_5468795.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Monument_Underground_Station_-_geograph.org.uk_-_5468795.jpg/216px-Monument_Underground_Station_-_geograph.org.uk_-_5468795.jpg" decoding="async" width="216" height="143" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Monument_Underground_Station_-_geograph.org.uk_-_5468795.jpg/324px-Monument_Underground_Station_-_geograph.org.uk_-_5468795.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Monument_Underground_Station_-_geograph.org.uk_-_5468795.jpg/432px-Monument_Underground_Station_-_geograph.org.uk_-_5468795.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="425" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/London_Underground#Roundel" title="London Underground">roundel symbol</a> designed by <a href="/wiki/Edward_Johnston" title="Edward Johnston">Edward Johnston</a> and trademarked in 1917</div></div></div></div></div>

<p>Opened in 1863, the <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London Underground</a>, commonly referred to as the Tube or just the Underground, is the oldest and third longest <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">metro</a> system in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>285<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>286<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The system serves <a href="/wiki/List_of_London_Underground_stations" title="List of London Underground stations">272 stations</a>, and was formed from several private companies, including the world's first underground electric line, the <a href="/wiki/City_and_South_London_Railway" title="City and South London Railway">City and South London Railway</a>, which opened in 1890.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>287<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Over 4&#160;million journeys are made every day on the Underground network, over 1&#160;billion each year.<sup id="cite_ref-london_124_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_124-296"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>288<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> An investment programme is attempting to reduce congestion and improve reliability, including £6.5&#160;billion (€7.7&#160;billion) spent before the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>289<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Docklands_Light_Railway" title="Docklands Light Railway">Docklands Light Railway (DLR)</a>, which opened in 1987, is a second, more <a href="/wiki/Medium-capacity_rail_transport_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Medium-capacity rail transport system">local metro system</a> using smaller and lighter tram-type vehicles that serve the <a href="/wiki/London_Docklands" title="London Docklands">Docklands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greenwich" title="Greenwich">Greenwich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lewisham" title="Lewisham">Lewisham</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>290<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Suburban">Suburban</h4></div>

<p>There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_London_railway_stations" title="List of London railway stations">368 railway stations</a> in the <a href="/wiki/London_fare_zones" title="London fare zones">London Travelcard Zones</a> on an extensive above-ground suburban railway network. South London, particularly, has a high concentration of railways as it has fewer Underground lines. Most rail lines terminate around the centre of London, running into <a href="/wiki/London_station_group" title="London station group">eighteen terminal stations</a>, with the exception of the <a href="/wiki/Thameslink_(route)" class="mw-redirect" title="Thameslink (route)">Thameslink</a> trains connecting <a href="/wiki/Bedford" title="Bedford">Bedford</a> in the north and <a href="/wiki/Brighton" title="Brighton">Brighton</a> in the south via <a href="/wiki/London_Luton_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="London Luton Airport">Luton</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gatwick_Airport" title="Gatwick Airport">Gatwick</a> airports.<sup id="cite_ref-london_127_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_127-299"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London has Britain's busiest station&#160;by number of passengers—<a href="/wiki/London_Waterloo_station" title="London Waterloo station">Waterloo</a>, with over 184&#160;million people using the interchange station complex (which includes <a href="/wiki/London_Waterloo_East_railway_station" class="mw-redirect" title="London Waterloo East railway station">Waterloo East</a> station) each year.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>292<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Clapham_Junction_railway_station" title="Clapham Junction railway station">Clapham Junction</a> is one of Europe's busiest rail interchanges.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>293<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>With the need for more rail capacity, the <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_line" title="Elizabeth line">Elizabeth Line</a> (also known as Crossrail) opened in May 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>294<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is a new railway line running east to west through London and into the <a href="/wiki/Home_Counties" class="mw-redirect" title="Home Counties">Home Counties</a> with a branch to Heathrow Airport.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>295<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It was Europe's biggest construction project, with a £15&#160;billion projected cost.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>296<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Inter-city_and_international">Inter-city and international</h4></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/220px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="186" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/330px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/440px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg 2x" data-file-width="8466" data-file-height="7140" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/St_Pancras_railway_station" title="St Pancras railway station">St Pancras International</a> is the main terminal for high-speed <a href="/wiki/Eurostar" title="Eurostar">Eurostar</a> and <a href="/wiki/High_Speed_1" title="High Speed 1">High Speed 1</a> services, as well as commuter suburban Thameslink and inter-city <a href="/wiki/East_Midlands_Railway" title="East Midlands Railway">East Midlands Railway</a> services.</figcaption></figure>

<p>London is the centre of the <a href="/wiki/National_Rail" title="National Rail">National Rail</a> network, with 70% of rail journeys starting or ending in London.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>297<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/London_King%27s_Cross_railway_station" title="London King&#39;s Cross railway station">King's Cross station</a> and <a href="/wiki/Euston_railway_station" title="Euston railway station">Euston station</a>, both in London, are the starting points of the <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_Main_Line" title="East Coast Main Line">East Coast Main Line</a> and the <a href="/wiki/West_Coast_Main_Line" title="West Coast Main Line">West Coast Main Line</a> – the two main railway lines in Britain. Like suburban rail services, regional and inter-city trains depart from several termini around the city centre, directly linking London with most of Great Britain's major cities and towns.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>298<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Flying_Scotsman_(train)" class="mw-redirect" title="Flying Scotsman (train)">The Flying Scotsman</a></i> is an express passenger train service that has operated between London and Edinburgh since 1862; the world famous steam locomotive named after this service, <a href="/wiki/LNER_Class_A3_4472_Flying_Scotsman" title="LNER Class A3 4472 Flying Scotsman"><i>Flying Scotsman</i></a>, was the first locomotive to reach the officially authenticated speed of 100&#160;miles per hour (161&#160;km/h) in 1934.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>299<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Some international railway services to <a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">Continental Europe</a> were operated during the 20th century as <a href="/wiki/Boat_train" title="Boat train">boat trains</a>. The opening of the <a href="/wiki/Channel_Tunnel" title="Channel Tunnel">Channel Tunnel</a> in 1994 connected London directly to the continental rail network, allowing <a href="/wiki/Eurostar" title="Eurostar">Eurostar</a> services to begin. Since 2007, high-speed trains link <a href="/wiki/St_Pancras_railway_station" title="St Pancras railway station">St. Pancras International</a> with <a href="/wiki/Lille" title="Lille">Lille</a>, <a href="/wiki/Calais" title="Calais">Calais</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Paris" title="Disneyland Paris">Disneyland Paris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">Brussels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amsterdam" title="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a> and other European tourist destinations via the <a href="/wiki/High_Speed_1" title="High Speed 1">High Speed 1</a> rail link and the Channel Tunnel.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>300<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The first <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_(train_operating_company)" title="Southeastern (train operating company)">high-speed domestic</a> trains started in June 2009, linking <a href="/wiki/Kent" title="Kent">Kent</a> to London.<sup id="cite_ref-Southeastern_Highspeed_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Southeastern_Highspeed-309"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>301<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are plans for a <a href="/wiki/High_Speed_2" title="High Speed 2">second high speed line</a> linking London to the Midlands, North West England, and Yorkshire.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>302<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Buses,_coaches_and_trams"><span id="Buses.2C_coaches_and_trams"></span>Buses, coaches and trams</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:396px;max-width:396px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:LTZ1423-15-20240430-193650.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/LTZ1423-15-20240430-193650.jpg/250px-LTZ1423-15-20240430-193650.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/LTZ1423-15-20240430-193650.jpg/375px-LTZ1423-15-20240430-193650.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/LTZ1423-15-20240430-193650.jpg/500px-LTZ1423-15-20240430-193650.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3448" data-file-height="2299" /></a></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:140px;max-width:140px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:East_London_Routemaster_bus_RM2050_(ALM_50B)_heritage_route_15_St_Pauls_5_December_2005.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/East_London_Routemaster_bus_RM2050_%28ALM_50B%29_heritage_route_15_St_Pauls_5_December_2005.jpg/138px-East_London_Routemaster_bus_RM2050_%28ALM_50B%29_heritage_route_15_St_Pauls_5_December_2005.jpg" decoding="async" width="138" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/East_London_Routemaster_bus_RM2050_%28ALM_50B%29_heritage_route_15_St_Pauls_5_December_2005.jpg/207px-East_London_Routemaster_bus_RM2050_%28ALM_50B%29_heritage_route_15_St_Pauls_5_December_2005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/East_London_Routemaster_bus_RM2050_%28ALM_50B%29_heritage_route_15_St_Pauls_5_December_2005.jpg/276px-East_London_Routemaster_bus_RM2050_%28ALM_50B%29_heritage_route_15_St_Pauls_5_December_2005.jpg 2x" data-file-width="787" data-file-height="950" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/New_Routemaster" title="New Routemaster">New Routemaster</a> (left) is the spiritual successor to the <a href="/wiki/AEC_Routemaster" title="AEC Routemaster">AEC Routemaster</a> (right). First appearing in 1947, the red double-decker bus is an emblematic symbol of London.</div></div></div></div>

<p>London's <a href="/wiki/London_Buses" title="London Buses">bus network</a> runs 24 hours a day with about 9,300 vehicles, over 675 bus routes and about 19,000 bus stops.<sup id="cite_ref-Buses_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buses-311"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>303<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2019 the network had over 2&#160;billion commuter trips per year.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>304<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since 2010 an average of £1.2&#160;billion is taken in revenue each year.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London has one of the largest wheelchair-accessible networks in the world<sup id="cite_ref-london_131_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_131-314"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>306<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and from the third quarter of 2007, became more accessible to hearing and visually impaired passengers as audio-visual announcements were introduced.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>307<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>An emblem of London, the red <a href="/wiki/Double-decker_bus" title="Double-decker bus">double-decker bus</a> first appeared in the city in 1947 with the <a href="/wiki/AEC_Regent_III_RT" title="AEC Regent III RT">AEC Regent III RT</a> (predecessor to the <a href="/wiki/AEC_Routemaster" title="AEC Routemaster">AEC Routemaster</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>308<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London's coach hub is <a href="/wiki/Victoria_Coach_Station" title="Victoria Coach Station">Victoria Coach Station</a>, opened in 1932. Nationalised in 1970 and then purchased by London Transport (now <a href="/wiki/Transport_for_London" title="Transport for London">Transport for London</a>), Victoria Coach Station has over 14&#160;million passengers a year and provides services across the UK and continental Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>309<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Wimbledon_station_2018_5.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Wimbledon_station_2018_5.jpg/220px-Wimbledon_station_2018_5.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Wimbledon_station_2018_5.jpg/330px-Wimbledon_station_2018_5.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Wimbledon_station_2018_5.jpg/440px-Wimbledon_station_2018_5.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Tramlink" title="Tramlink">Tramlink</a> tram at <a href="/wiki/Wimbledon_station" title="Wimbledon station">Wimbledon station</a>, south-west London</figcaption></figure>

<p>There is a modern tram network serving South London, known as <a href="/wiki/Tramlink" title="Tramlink">Tramlink</a>. It has 39 stops and four routes, and carried over 29&#160;million people in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>310<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since June 2008, Transport for London has completely owned and operated Tramlink.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Cable_car">Cable car</h3></div>

<p>London's first and to date only cable car is the <a href="/wiki/London_Cable_Car" class="mw-redirect" title="London Cable Car">London Cable Car</a>, which opened in June 2012. The cable car crosses the Thames and links <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Peninsula" title="Greenwich Peninsula">Greenwich Peninsula</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Docks" title="Royal Docks">Royal Docks</a> in the east of the city. It is able to carry up to 2,500 passengers per hour in each direction at peak times.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>312<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Cycling">Cycling</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cycling_in_London" title="Cycling in London">Cycling in London</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Belgrave_Road,_Victoria,_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg/220px-Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg/330px-Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg/440px-Belgrave_Road%2C_Victoria%2C_London_-_Boris_Bikes_-_Santander_Cycles_by_Elliott_Brown.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="3216" /></a><figcaption>Santander Cycle Hire, near <a href="/wiki/Victoria,_London" title="Victoria, London">Victoria</a> in Central London</figcaption></figure>

<p>In the Greater London Area, around 670,000 people use a bike every day,<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>313<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> meaning around 7% of the total population of around 8.8&#160;million use a bike on an average day.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>314<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Cycling has become an increasingly popular way to get around London. The launch of a <a href="/wiki/Bicycle-sharing_system" title="Bicycle-sharing system">bicycle hire scheme</a> in July 2010 was successful and generally well received.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>315<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Port_and_river_boats">Port and river boats</h3></div>

<p>The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_London" title="Port of London">Port of London</a>, once the largest in the world, is now only the second-largest in the United Kingdom, handling 45&#160;million tonnes of cargo each year as of 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-handling_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-handling-324"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>316<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Most of this cargo passes through the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Tilbury" title="Port of Tilbury">Port of Tilbury</a>, outside the boundary of Greater London.<sup id="cite_ref-handling_324-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-handling-324"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>316<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>London has river boat services on the Thames known as <a href="/wiki/Thames_Clippers" title="Thames Clippers">Thames Clippers</a>, which offer both commuter and tourist boat services.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>317<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> At major piers including <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf_Pier" title="Canary Wharf Pier">Canary Wharf</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Bridge_City_Pier" title="London Bridge City Pier">London Bridge City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battersea_Power_Station" title="Battersea Power Station">Battersea Power Station</a> and <a href="/wiki/London_Eye_Pier" title="London Eye Pier">London Eye</a> (Waterloo), services depart at least every 20 minutes during commuter times.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>318<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Woolwich_Ferry" title="Woolwich Ferry">Woolwich Ferry</a>, with 2.5&#160;million passengers every year, is a frequent service linking the <a href="/wiki/North_Circular_Road,_London" class="mw-redirect" title="North Circular Road, London">North</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Circular_Road,_London" title="South Circular Road, London">South Circular</a> Roads.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>319<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Roads">Roads</h3></div>

<p>Although the majority of journeys in central London are made by public transport, car travel is common in the suburbs. The <a href="/wiki/London_Inner_Ring_Road" title="London Inner Ring Road">inner ring road</a> (around the city centre), the <a href="/wiki/A406_road" class="mw-redirect" title="A406 road">North</a> and <a href="/wiki/A205_road" class="mw-redirect" title="A205 road">South Circular</a> roads (just within the suburbs), and the outer orbital motorway (the <a href="/wiki/M25_motorway" title="M25 motorway">M25</a>, just outside the built-up area in most places) encircle the city and are intersected by a number of busy radial routes—but very few motorways penetrate into <a href="/wiki/Inner_London" title="Inner London">inner London</a>. The M25 is the second-longest ring-road motorway in Europe at 117 miles (188&#160;km) long.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>320<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/A1_road_(Great_Britain)" title="A1 road (Great Britain)">A1</a> and <a href="/wiki/M1_motorway" title="M1 motorway">M1</a> connect London to <a href="/wiki/Leeds" title="Leeds">Leeds</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_upon_Tyne" title="Newcastle upon Tyne">Newcastle</a> and <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>321<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:16-11-16-Glasgow_street_scene-RR2_7280_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/16-11-16-Glasgow_street_scene-RR2_7280_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-16-11-16-Glasgow_street_scene-RR2_7280_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="151" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/16-11-16-Glasgow_street_scene-RR2_7280_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-16-11-16-Glasgow_street_scene-RR2_7280_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/16-11-16-Glasgow_street_scene-RR2_7280_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-16-11-16-Glasgow_street_scene-RR2_7280_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3040" data-file-height="2092" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Hackney_carriage" title="Hackney carriage">hackney carriage</a> (black cab) is a common sight on London streets. Black has been its standard colour since the <a href="/wiki/Austin_FX3" title="Austin FX3">Austin FX3</a> model in 1948.</figcaption></figure>

<p>The <a href="/wiki/Austin_Motor_Company" title="Austin Motor Company">Austin Motor Company</a> began making <a href="/wiki/Hackney_carriage" title="Hackney carriage">hackney carriages</a> (London taxis) in 1929, and models include <a href="/wiki/Austin_FX3" title="Austin FX3">Austin FX3</a> from 1948, <a href="/wiki/Austin_FX4" title="Austin FX4">Austin FX4</a> from 1958, with more recent models <a href="/wiki/TXII" title="TXII">TXII</a> and <a href="/wiki/TX4" title="TX4">TX4</a> manufactured by <a href="/wiki/London_Taxis_International" class="mw-redirect" title="London Taxis International">London Taxis International</a>. The BBC states, "ubiquitous black cabs and red double-decker buses all have long and tangled stories that are deeply embedded in London's traditions".<sup id="cite_ref-London_traditions_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-London_traditions-330"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>322<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

Although traditionally black, some are painted in other colours or bear advertising.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>323<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>London is notorious for its traffic congestion; in 2009, the average speed of a car in the rush hour was recorded at 10.6&#160;mph (17.1&#160;km/h).<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2003, a <a href="/wiki/London_congestion_charge" title="London congestion charge">congestion charge</a> was introduced to reduce traffic volumes in the city centre. With a few exceptions, motorists are required to pay to drive within a defined zone encompassing much of central London.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>325<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Motorists who are residents of the defined zone can buy a greatly reduced season pass.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Over the course of several years, the average number of cars entering the centre of London on a weekday was reduced from 195,000 to 125,000.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>327<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p><a href="/wiki/Low_Traffic_Neighbourhood" title="Low Traffic Neighbourhood">Low Traffic Neighbourhoods (LTN)</a> were widely introduced in London, but in 2023 the Department for Transport stopped funding them, even though the benefits outweighed the costs by approximately 100 times in the first 20&#160;years and the difference is growing over time.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>328<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Education">Education</h2></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_London" title="Education in London">Education in London</a></div>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Tertiary_education">Tertiary education</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_and_higher_education_colleges_in_London" title="List of universities and higher education colleges in London">List of universities and higher education colleges in London</a></div>
