<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:University_College_London_-quadrant-11Sept2006_(1).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/University_College_London_-quadrant-11Sept2006_%281%29.jpg/220px-University_College_London_-quadrant-11Sept2006_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="172" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/University_College_London_-quadrant-11Sept2006_%281%29.jpg/330px-University_College_London_-quadrant-11Sept2006_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/University_College_London_-quadrant-11Sept2006_%281%29.jpg/440px-University_College_London_-quadrant-11Sept2006_%281%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3132" data-file-height="2447" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/University_College_London" title="University College London">University College London</a> (UCL), established by Royal Charter in 1836, is one of the founding colleges of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_London" title="University of London">University of London</a>.</figcaption></figure>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Imperial_College_London_down_Exhibition_Road.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Imperial_College_London_down_Exhibition_Road.jpg/220px-Imperial_College_London_down_Exhibition_Road.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="161" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Imperial_College_London_down_Exhibition_Road.jpg/330px-Imperial_College_London_down_Exhibition_Road.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Imperial_College_London_down_Exhibition_Road.jpg/440px-Imperial_College_London_down_Exhibition_Road.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4096" data-file-height="2998" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_London" title="Imperial College London">Imperial College London</a>, a technical research university focusing on science, engineering, medicine and business, in <a href="/wiki/South_Kensington" title="South Kensington">South Kensington</a></figcaption></figure>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Centre_Building,_LSE_from_LSE_Square.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Centre_Building%2C_LSE_from_LSE_Square.jpg/220px-Centre_Building%2C_LSE_from_LSE_Square.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Centre_Building%2C_LSE_from_LSE_Square.jpg/330px-Centre_Building%2C_LSE_from_LSE_Square.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Centre_Building%2C_LSE_from_LSE_Square.jpg/440px-Centre_Building%2C_LSE_from_LSE_Square.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/London_School_of_Economics" title="London School of Economics">London School of Economics</a> (Centre Building pictured) was established in 1895</figcaption></figure>

<p>London is a major global centre of higher education teaching and research and has the largest concentration of higher education institutes in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-london2_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london2-27"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to the QS World University Rankings 2015/16, London has the greatest concentration of top class universities in the world<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>329<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and its international student population of around 110,000 is larger than any other city in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>330<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A 2014 <a href="/wiki/PricewaterhouseCoopers" class="mw-redirect" title="PricewaterhouseCoopers">PricewaterhouseCoopers</a> report termed London the global capital of higher education.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>331<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

A number of world-leading education institutions are based in London. In the 2022 <i><a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_London" title="Imperial College London">Imperial College London</a> is ranked No. 6 in the world, <a href="/wiki/University_College_London" title="University College London">University College London</a> (UCL) is ranked 8th, and <a href="/wiki/King%27s_College_London" title="King&#39;s College London">King's College London</a> (KCL) is ranked 37th.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>332<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> All are regularly ranked highly, with Imperial College being the UK's leading university in the <a href="/wiki/Research_Excellence_Framework" title="Research Excellence Framework">Research Excellence Framework</a> ranking 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>333<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/London_School_of_Economics" title="London School of Economics">London School of Economics</a> (LSE) has been described as the world's leading social science institution for both teaching and research.<sup id="cite_ref-london_156_342-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_156-342"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>334<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/London_Business_School" title="London Business School">London Business School</a> is considered one of the world's leading business schools and in 2015 its MBA programme was ranked second-best in the world by the <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Times" title="Financial Times">Financial Times</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-ft_343-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ft-343"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>335<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The city is also home to three of the world's top ten performing arts schools (as ranked by the 2020 QS World University Rankings<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>336<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>): the <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Music" title="Royal College of Music">Royal College of Music</a> (ranking 2nd in the world), the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Music" title="Royal Academy of Music">Royal Academy of Music</a> (ranking 4th) and the <a href="/wiki/Guildhall_School_of_Music_and_Drama" title="Guildhall School of Music and Drama">Guildhall School of Music and Drama</a> (ranking 6th).<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>337<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>With students in London and around 48,000 in <a href="/wiki/University_of_London_Worldwide" title="University of London Worldwide">University of London Worldwide</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-External_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-External-346"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>338<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the federal <a href="/wiki/University_of_London" title="University of London">University of London</a> is the largest contact teaching university in the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>339<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It includes five multi-faculty universities – <a href="/wiki/City,_University_of_London" title="City, University of London">City</a>, King's College London, <a href="/wiki/Queen_Mary,_University_of_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Queen Mary, University of London">Queen Mary</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Holloway" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal Holloway">Royal Holloway</a> and UCL – and a number of smaller and more specialised institutions including <a href="/wiki/Birkbeck_College" class="mw-redirect" title="Birkbeck College">Birkbeck</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Courtauld_Institute_of_Art" title="Courtauld Institute of Art">Courtauld Institute of Art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goldsmiths,_University_of_London" title="Goldsmiths, University of London">Goldsmiths</a>, the London Business School, the London School of Economics, the <a href="/wiki/London_School_of_Hygiene_%26_Tropical_Medicine" title="London School of Hygiene &amp; Tropical Medicine">London School of Hygiene &amp; Tropical Medicine</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Music" title="Royal Academy of Music">Royal Academy of Music</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Central_School_of_Speech_and_Drama" class="mw-redirect" title="Central School of Speech and Drama">Central School of Speech and Drama</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Veterinary_College" title="Royal Veterinary College">Royal Veterinary College</a> and the <a href="/wiki/School_of_Oriental_and_African_Studies" class="mw-redirect" title="School of Oriental and African Studies">School of Oriental and African Studies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>340<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Universities in London outside the University of London system include <a href="/wiki/Brunel_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Brunel University">Brunel University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_London" title="Imperial College London">Imperial College London</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>h<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kingston_University" title="Kingston University">Kingston University</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Metropolitan_University" title="London Metropolitan University">London Metropolitan University</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_East_London" title="University of East London">University of East London</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_West_London" title="University of West London">University of West London</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Westminster" title="University of Westminster">University of Westminster</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_South_Bank_University" title="London South Bank University">London South Bank University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Middlesex_University" title="Middlesex University">Middlesex University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Arts_London" title="University of the Arts London">University of the Arts London</a> (the largest university of art, design, fashion, communication and the performing arts in Europe).<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>341<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In addition, there are three international universities – <a href="/wiki/Regent%27s_College" class="mw-redirect" title="Regent&#39;s College">Regent's University London</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richmond,_The_American_International_University_in_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Richmond, The American International University in London">Richmond, The American International University in London</a> and <a href="/wiki/Schiller_International_University" title="Schiller International University">Schiller International University</a>.

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:KCL_Guys_Campus1.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/KCL_Guys_Campus1.jpg/220px-KCL_Guys_Campus1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="200" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/KCL_Guys_Campus1.jpg/330px-KCL_Guys_Campus1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/KCL_Guys_Campus1.jpg/440px-KCL_Guys_Campus1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="540" data-file-height="491" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/King%27s_College_London" title="King&#39;s College London">King's College London</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Guy%27s_Campus" title="Guy&#39;s Campus">Guy's Campus</a>, home to the university's <a href="/wiki/King%27s_College_London_School_of_Medicine" class="mw-redirect" title="King&#39;s College London School of Medicine">Faculty of Life Sciences &amp; Medicine</a></figcaption></figure>

<p>London is home to <a href="/wiki/United_Hospitals" title="United Hospitals">five major medical schools</a>&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Barts_and_The_London_School_of_Medicine_and_Dentistry" title="Barts and The London School of Medicine and Dentistry">Barts and The London School of Medicine and Dentistry</a> (part of <a href="/wiki/Queen_Mary,_University_of_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Queen Mary, University of London">Queen Mary</a>), <a href="/wiki/King%27s_College_London_School_of_Medicine" class="mw-redirect" title="King&#39;s College London School of Medicine">King's College London School of Medicine</a> (the largest medical school in Europe), <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_School_of_Medicine" title="Imperial College School of Medicine">Imperial College School of Medicine</a>, <a href="/wiki/UCL_Medical_School" title="UCL Medical School">UCL Medical School</a> and <a href="/wiki/St_George%27s,_University_of_London" title="St George&#39;s, University of London">St George's, University of London</a>&#160;– and has many affiliated teaching hospitals. It is also a major centre for biomedical research, and three of the UK's eight <a href="/wiki/Academic_health_science_centre" class="mw-redirect" title="Academic health science centre">academic health science centres</a> are based in the city&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_Healthcare_NHS_Trust" title="Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust">Imperial College Healthcare</a>, <a href="/wiki/King%27s_Health_Partners" title="King&#39;s Health Partners">King's Health Partners</a> and <a href="/wiki/UCL_Partners" class="mw-redirect" title="UCL Partners">UCL Partners</a> (the largest such centre in Europe).<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>342<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Additionally, many biomedical and biotechnology spin out companies from these research institutions are based around the city, most prominently in <a href="/wiki/White_City,_London" title="White City, London">White City</a>. Founded by pioneering nurse <a href="/wiki/Florence_Nightingale" title="Florence Nightingale">Florence Nightingale</a> at <a href="/wiki/St_Thomas%27_Hospital" title="St Thomas&#39; Hospital">St Thomas' Hospital</a> in 1860, the <a href="/wiki/Florence_Nightingale_Faculty_of_Nursing_and_Midwifery" title="Florence Nightingale Faculty of Nursing and Midwifery">first nursing school</a> is now part of King's College London.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>343<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It was at King's in 1952 where a team led by <a href="/wiki/Rosalind_Franklin" title="Rosalind Franklin">Rosalind Franklin</a> captured <i><a href="/wiki/Photo_51" title="Photo 51">Photo 51</a></i>, the critical evidence in identifying the structure of <a href="/wiki/DNA" title="DNA">DNA</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>344<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are a number of business schools in London, including the <a href="/wiki/London_School_of_Business_and_Finance" title="London School of Business and Finance">London School of Business and Finance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cass_Business_School" class="mw-redirect" title="Cass Business School">Cass Business School</a> (part of <a href="/wiki/City_University_London" class="mw-redirect" title="City University London">City University London</a>), <a href="/wiki/Hult_International_Business_School" title="Hult International Business School">Hult International Business School</a>, <a href="/wiki/ESCP_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="ESCP Europe">ESCP Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Business_School_London" title="European Business School London">European Business School London</a>, <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_Business_School" title="Imperial College Business School">Imperial College Business School</a>, the <a href="/wiki/London_Business_School" title="London Business School">London Business School</a> and the <a href="/wiki/UCL_School_of_Management" title="UCL School of Management">UCL School of Management</a>.

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2492593.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2492593.jpg/200px-Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2492593.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="267" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2492593.jpg/300px-Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2492593.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2492593.jpg/400px-Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2492593.jpg 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="640" /></a><figcaption>Opened in 1904, <a href="/wiki/RADA" class="mw-redirect" title="RADA">RADA</a> (Royal Academy of Dramatic Art) is a member of the UK's <a href="/wiki/Federation_of_Drama_Schools" title="Federation of Drama Schools">Federation of Drama Schools</a>.</figcaption></figure>

<p>London is also home to many specialist arts education institutions, including esteemed drama schools such as <a href="/wiki/RADA" class="mw-redirect" title="RADA">RADA</a> (Royal Academy of Dramatic Art), the <a href="/wiki/London_Academy_of_Music_and_Dramatic_Art" title="London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art">London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art</a> (LAMDA), <a href="/wiki/Drama_Studio_London" title="Drama Studio London">Drama Studio London</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sylvia_Young_Theatre_School" title="Sylvia Young Theatre School">Sylvia Young Theatre School</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Central_School_of_Speech_and_Drama" title="Royal Central School of Speech and Drama">Royal Central School of Speech and Drama</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Guildhall_School_of_Music_and_Drama" title="Guildhall School of Music and Drama">Guildhall School of Music and Drama</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/London_College_of_Contemporary_Arts" class="mw-redirect" title="London College of Contemporary Arts">London College of Contemporary Arts</a> (LCCA), <a href="/wiki/Central_School_of_Ballet" title="Central School of Ballet">Central School of Ballet</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Contemporary_Dance_School" title="London Contemporary Dance School">London Contemporary Dance School</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Circus_Space" class="mw-redirect" title="The Circus Space">National Centre for Circus Arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rambert_Dance_Company" title="Rambert Dance Company">Rambert School of Ballet and Contemporary Dance</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Art" title="Royal College of Art">Royal College of Art</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Trinity_Laban_Conservatoire_of_Music_and_Dance" title="Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance">Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance</a>. The <a href="/wiki/BRIT_School" title="BRIT School">BRIT School</a> in the London borough of Croydon provides training for the performing arts and technologies.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>345<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Primary_and_secondary_education">Primary and secondary education</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Centre_for_School_Design" title="Centre for School Design">Centre for School Design</a></div>

<p>The majority of primary and secondary schools and further-education colleges in London are controlled by the <a href="/wiki/London_boroughs" title="London boroughs">London boroughs</a> or otherwise state-funded; leading examples include <a href="/wiki/Ashbourne_College" title="Ashbourne College">Ashbourne College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bethnal_Green_Academy" class="mw-redirect" title="Bethnal Green Academy">Bethnal Green Academy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brampton_Manor_Academy" title="Brampton Manor Academy">Brampton Manor Academy</a>, <a href="/wiki/City_and_Islington_College" title="City and Islington College">City and Islington College</a>, <a href="/wiki/City_of_Westminster_College" title="City of Westminster College">City of Westminster College</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Game_College" title="David Game College">David Game College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ealing,_Hammersmith_and_West_London_College" class="mw-redirect" title="Ealing, Hammersmith and West London College">Ealing, Hammersmith and West London College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leyton_Sixth_Form_College" title="Leyton Sixth Form College">Leyton Sixth Form College</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_Academy_of_Excellence" title="London Academy of Excellence">London Academy of Excellence</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tower_Hamlets_College" class="mw-redirect" title="Tower Hamlets College">Tower Hamlets College</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Newham_Collegiate_Sixth_Form_Centre" title="Newham Collegiate Sixth Form Centre">Newham Collegiate Sixth Form Centre</a>. There are also a number of private schools and colleges in London, some old and famous, such as <a href="/wiki/City_of_London_School" title="City of London School">City of London School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Harrow_School" title="Harrow School">Harrow</a> (alumni includes seven former British prime ministers), <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_School,_London" title="St Paul&#39;s School, London">St Paul's School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haberdashers%27_Aske%27s_Boys%27_School" class="mw-redirect" title="Haberdashers&#39; Aske&#39;s Boys&#39; School">Haberdashers' Aske's Boys' School</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_College_School" title="University College School">University College School</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_John_Lyon_School" class="mw-redirect" title="The John Lyon School">The John Lyon School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Highgate_School" title="Highgate School">Highgate School</a> and <a href="/wiki/Westminster_School" title="Westminster School">Westminster School</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>346<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich_and_learned_societies"><span id="Royal_Observatory.2C_Greenwich_and_learned_societies"></span>Royal Observatory, Greenwich and learned societies</h3></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Tourists_taking_pictures_at_Prime_Meridian_monument,_Greenwich_Observatory,_London.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Tourists_taking_pictures_at_Prime_Meridian_monument%2C_Greenwich_Observatory%2C_London.jpg/220px-Tourists_taking_pictures_at_Prime_Meridian_monument%2C_Greenwich_Observatory%2C_London.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Tourists_taking_pictures_at_Prime_Meridian_monument%2C_Greenwich_Observatory%2C_London.jpg/330px-Tourists_taking_pictures_at_Prime_Meridian_monument%2C_Greenwich_Observatory%2C_London.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Tourists_taking_pictures_at_Prime_Meridian_monument%2C_Greenwich_Observatory%2C_London.jpg/440px-Tourists_taking_pictures_at_Prime_Meridian_monument%2C_Greenwich_Observatory%2C_London.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5928" data-file-height="3894" /></a><figcaption>Tourists queuing to take pictures on the line of the historic <a href="/wiki/Prime_meridian_(Greenwich)" title="Prime meridian (Greenwich)">prime meridian</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich" title="Royal Observatory, Greenwich">Royal Observatory, Greenwich</a>.</figcaption></figure>

<p>Founded in 1675, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich" title="Royal Observatory, Greenwich">Royal Observatory</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich" title="Greenwich">Greenwich</a> was established to address the problem of calculating <a href="/wiki/Longitude" title="Longitude">longitude</a> for navigational purposes. This pioneering work in solving longitude featured in astronomer royal <a href="/wiki/Nevil_Maskelyne" title="Nevil Maskelyne">Nevil Maskelyne</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Nautical_Almanac" class="mw-redirect" title="Nautical Almanac">Nautical Almanac</a></i> which made the Greenwich meridian the universal reference point, and helped lead to the international adoption of Greenwich as the <a href="/wiki/Prime_meridian" title="Prime meridian">prime meridian</a> (0° longitude) in 1884.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>347<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Important scientific <a href="/wiki/Learned_societies" class="mw-redirect" title="Learned societies">learned societies</a> based in London include the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Society" title="Royal Society">Royal Society</a>—the UK's national <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_sciences" title="Academy of sciences">academy of sciences</a> and the oldest national scientific institution in the world—founded in 1660,<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>348<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Institution" title="Royal Institution">Royal Institution</a>, founded in 1799. Since 1825, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Institution_Christmas_Lectures" title="Royal Institution Christmas Lectures">Royal Institution Christmas Lectures</a> have presented scientific subjects to a general audience, and speakers have included physicist and inventor <a href="/wiki/Michael_Faraday" title="Michael Faraday">Michael Faraday</a>, aerospace engineer <a href="/wiki/Frank_Whittle" title="Frank Whittle">Frank Whittle</a>, naturalist <a href="/wiki/David_Attenborough" title="David Attenborough">David Attenborough</a> and evolutionary biologist <a href="/wiki/Richard_Dawkins" title="Richard Dawkins">Richard Dawkins</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>349<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Culture">Culture</h2></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_London" title="Culture of London">Culture of London</a></div>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Leisure_and_entertainment">Leisure and entertainment</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_annual_events_in_London" title="List of annual events in London">List of annual events in London</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_End_theatre" title="West End theatre">West End theatre</a></div>

<p>Leisure is a major part of the London economy. A 2003 report attributed a quarter of the entire UK leisure economy to London<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> at 25.6 events per 1000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>351<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The city is one of the four <a href="/wiki/Fashion_capital" title="Fashion capital">fashion capitals</a> of the world, and, according to official statistics, is the world's third-busiest film production centre, presents more live comedy than any other city,<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>352<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and has the biggest theatre audience of any city in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>353<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Harrods_at_Night,_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg/170px-Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="202" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg/255px-Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg/340px-Harrods_at_Night%2C_London_-_Nov_2012.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2948" data-file-height="3500" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Harrods" title="Harrods">Harrods</a> department store in <a href="/wiki/Knightsbridge" title="Knightsbridge">Knightsbridge</a></figcaption></figure>

<p>Within the <a href="/wiki/City_of_Westminster" title="City of Westminster">City of Westminster</a>, the entertainment district of the <a href="/wiki/West_End_of_London" title="West End of London">West End</a> has its focus around <a href="/wiki/Leicester_Square" title="Leicester Square">Leicester Square</a>, where London and world film <a href="/wiki/Premiere" title="Premiere">premieres</a> are held, and <a href="/wiki/Piccadilly_Circus" title="Piccadilly Circus">Piccadilly Circus</a>, with its giant electronic advertisements.<sup id="cite_ref-london_160_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_160-363"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>354<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London's <a href="/wiki/West_End_theatre" title="West End theatre">theatre district</a> is here, as are many cinemas, bars, clubs, and restaurants, including the city's <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_London" title="Chinatown, London">Chinatown</a> district (in <a href="/wiki/Soho" title="Soho">Soho</a>), and just to the east is <a href="/wiki/Royal_Opera_House" title="Royal Opera House">Covent Garden</a>, an area housing speciality shops. In 1881, the West End's <a href="/wiki/Savoy_Theatre" title="Savoy Theatre">Savoy Theatre</a>, which was built to showcase the plays of <a href="/wiki/Gilbert_and_Sullivan" title="Gilbert and Sullivan">Gilbert and Sullivan</a>, was fitted with the incandescent light bulb developed by Sir <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Swan" title="Joseph Swan">Joseph Swan</a> to become the first public building in the world to be lit entirely by electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>355<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The city is the home of <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Lloyd_Webber" title="Andrew Lloyd Webber">Andrew Lloyd Webber</a>, whose musicals have dominated West End theatre since the late 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>356<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Agatha_Christie" title="Agatha Christie">Agatha Christie</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Mousetrap" title="The Mousetrap">The Mousetrap</a></i>, the world's longest-running play, has been performed in the West End since 1952.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Olivier_Awards" title="Laurence Olivier Awards">Laurence Olivier Awards</a>–named after <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Olivier" title="Laurence Olivier">Laurence Olivier</a>–are given annually by the <a href="/wiki/Society_of_London_Theatre" title="Society of London Theatre">Society of London Theatre</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Ballet" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal Ballet">Royal Ballet</a>, <a href="/wiki/English_National_Ballet" title="English National Ballet">English National Ballet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Opera,_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal Opera, London">Royal Opera</a>, and <a href="/wiki/English_National_Opera" title="English National Opera">English National Opera</a> are based in London and perform at the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Opera_House" title="Royal Opera House">Royal Opera House</a>, the <a href="/wiki/London_Coliseum" title="London Coliseum">London Coliseum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sadler%27s_Wells_Theatre" title="Sadler&#39;s Wells Theatre">Sadler's Wells Theatre</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall" title="Royal Albert Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a>, as well as touring the country.<sup id="cite_ref-London&#39;s_Concerts_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-London&#39;s_Concerts-367"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>358<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p><a href="/wiki/Islington" title="Islington">Islington</a>'s 1 mile (1.6&#160;km) long <a href="/wiki/Upper_Street" title="Upper Street">Upper Street</a>, extending northwards from <a href="/wiki/Angel,_London" title="Angel, London">Angel</a>, has more bars and restaurants than any other street in the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-london_161_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-london_161-368"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Europe's busiest shopping area is <a href="/wiki/Oxford_Street" title="Oxford Street">Oxford Street</a>, a shopping street nearly 1 mile (1.6&#160;km) long, making it the longest shopping street in the UK. It is home to vast numbers of retailers and <a href="/wiki/Department_stores" class="mw-redirect" title="Department stores">department stores</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Selfridges" title="Selfridges">Selfridges</a> <a href="/wiki/Flagship_store#Retailing" class="mw-redirect" title="Flagship store">flagship store</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Knightsbridge" title="Knightsbridge">Knightsbridge</a>, home to the equally renowned <a href="/wiki/Harrods" title="Harrods">Harrods</a> department store, lies to the south-west. One of the world's largest retail destinations, London frequently ranks at or near the top of retail sales of any city.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>361<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>362<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Opened in 1760 with its flagship store on <a href="/wiki/Regent_Street" title="Regent Street">Regent Street</a> since 1881, <a href="/wiki/Hamleys" title="Hamleys">Hamleys</a> is the oldest <a href="/wiki/Toy_store" title="Toy store">toy store</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>363<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Boot_Company" title="British Boot Company">Camden Town shoe retailer</a> of <a href="/wiki/Dr._Martens" title="Dr. Martens">Dr. Martens</a> footwear was a favourite haunt of punk musicians.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>364<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Madame_Tussauds" title="Madame Tussauds">Madame Tussauds</a> wax museum opened in <a href="/wiki/Baker_Street" title="Baker Street">Baker Street</a> in 1835, an era viewed as being when London's tourism industry began.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>365<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Notting_hill_carnival.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Notting_hill_carnival.jpg/170px-Notting_hill_carnival.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Notting_hill_carnival.jpg/255px-Notting_hill_carnival.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Notting_hill_carnival.jpg/340px-Notting_hill_carnival.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1106" data-file-height="1474" /></a><figcaption>Scene of the annual <a href="/wiki/Notting_Hill_Carnival" title="Notting Hill Carnival">Notting Hill Carnival</a>, 2014</figcaption></figure>

<p>London is home to designers <a href="/wiki/John_Galliano" title="John Galliano">John Galliano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stella_McCartney" title="Stella McCartney">Stella McCartney</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manolo_Blahnik" title="Manolo Blahnik">Manolo Blahnik</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Choo" title="Jimmy Choo">Jimmy Choo</a>, among others; its renowned art and fashion schools make it one of the four international centres of fashion. <a href="/wiki/Mary_Quant" title="Mary Quant">Mary Quant</a> designed the <a href="/wiki/Miniskirt" title="Miniskirt">miniskirt</a> in her <a href="/wiki/King%27s_Road" title="King&#39;s Road">King's Road</a> boutique in <a href="/wiki/Swinging_Sixties" title="Swinging Sixties">Swinging Sixties London</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>366<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2017, London was ranked the top city for luxury store openings.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/London_Fashion_Week" title="London Fashion Week">London Fashion Week</a> takes place twice a year, in February and September; exhibitions have included <i><a href="/wiki/Jack_the_Ripper_Stalks_His_Victims" title="Jack the Ripper Stalks His Victims">Jack the Ripper Stalks His Victims</a></i>, the first collection by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_McQueen" title="Alexander McQueen">Alexander McQueen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Londoners on the catwalk have included <a href="/wiki/Naomi_Campbell" title="Naomi Campbell">Naomi Campbell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kate_Moss" title="Kate Moss">Kate Moss</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cara_Delevingne" title="Cara Delevingne">Cara Delevingne</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>369<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>London offers a great variety of cuisine as a result of its ethnically diverse population. Gastronomic centres include the Bangladeshi restaurants of <a href="/wiki/Brick_Lane" title="Brick Lane">Brick Lane</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_food" class="mw-redirect" title="Chinese food">Chinese</a> restaurants of <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_London" title="Chinatown, London">Chinatown</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>370<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are <a href="/wiki/Chinese_takeaway" class="mw-redirect" title="Chinese takeaway">Chinese takeaways</a> throughout London, as are Indian restaurants which provide <a href="/wiki/English_cuisine#Indian_and_Anglo-Indian_cuisine" title="English cuisine">Indian and Anglo-Indian cuisine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>371<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Around 1860, the first <a href="/wiki/Fish_and_chips" title="Fish and chips">fish and chips</a> shop in London was opened by Joseph Malin, a Jewish immigrant, in <a href="/wiki/Bow,_London" title="Bow, London">Bow</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-London_traditions_330-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-London_traditions-330"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>322<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Full_English_breakfast" class="mw-redirect" title="Full English breakfast">full English breakfast</a> dates from the Victorian era, and many <a href="/wiki/Cafe_(British)" title="Cafe (British)">cafes</a> in London serve a full English throughout the day.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>372<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London has five 3-Michelin star restaurants, including <a href="/wiki/Restaurant_Gordon_Ramsay" title="Restaurant Gordon Ramsay">Restaurant Gordon Ramsay</a> in <a href="/wiki/Chelsea,_London" title="Chelsea, London">Chelsea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>373<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Many hotels in London provide a traditional <a href="/wiki/Afternoon_tea" class="mw-redirect" title="Afternoon tea">afternoon tea</a> service, such as the <a href="/wiki/Hotel_Caf%C3%A9_Royal#Restoration_and_conversion" title="Hotel Café Royal">Oscar Wilde Lounge</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Hotel_Caf%C3%A9_Royal" title="Hotel Café Royal">Hotel Café Royal</a> in Piccadilly, and a themed tea service is also available, for example an <i><a href="/wiki/Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland" title="Alice&#39;s Adventures in Wonderland">Alice in Wonderland</a></i> themed afternoon tea served at the <a href="/wiki/Egerton_House_Hotel" title="Egerton House Hotel">Egerton House Hotel</a>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Charlie_and_the_Chocolate_Factory" title="Charlie and the Chocolate Factory">Charlie and the Chocolate Factory</a></i> themed afternoon tea at <a href="/wiki/One_Aldwych" title="One Aldwych">One Aldwych</a> in Covent Garden.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>374<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>375<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The nation's most popular <a href="/wiki/Biscuit" title="Biscuit">biscuit</a> to <a href="/wiki/Dunking_(biscuit)" title="Dunking (biscuit)">dunk</a> in tea, <a href="/wiki/Chocolate_digestive" class="mw-redirect" title="Chocolate digestive">chocolate digestives</a> have been manufactured by <a href="/wiki/McVitie%27s" title="McVitie&#39;s">McVitie's</a> at their <a href="/wiki/Harlesden" title="Harlesden">Harlesden</a> factory in north-west London since 1925.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Restaurante_The_Swan,_Londres,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-11,_DD_113.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg/220px-Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="173" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg/330px-Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg/440px-Restaurante_The_Swan%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_113.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4073" data-file-height="3212" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Shakespeare%27s_Globe" title="Shakespeare&#39;s Globe">Shakespeare's Globe</a> is a modern reconstruction of the Globe Theatre on the south bank of the Thames.</figcaption></figure>

<p>There is a variety of <a href="/wiki/List_of_annual_events_in_London" title="List of annual events in London">annual events</a>, beginning with the relatively new <a href="/wiki/New_Year%27s_Day_Parade" class="mw-redirect" title="New Year&#39;s Day Parade">New Year's Day Parade</a>, a fireworks display at the <a href="/wiki/London_Eye" title="London Eye">London Eye</a>; the world's second largest <a href="/wiki/Street_party" class="mw-redirect" title="Street party">street party</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Notting_Hill_Carnival" title="Notting Hill Carnival">Notting Hill Carnival</a>, is held on the late <a href="/wiki/August_Bank_Holiday" title="August Bank Holiday">August Bank Holiday</a> each year. Traditional parades include November's <a href="/wiki/Lord_Mayor%27s_Show" title="Lord Mayor&#39;s Show">Lord Mayor's Show</a>, a centuries-old event celebrating the annual appointment of a new <a href="/wiki/Lord_Mayor_of_the_City_of_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Lord Mayor of the City of London">Lord Mayor of the City of London</a> with a procession along the streets of the city, and June's <a href="/wiki/Trooping_the_Colour" title="Trooping the Colour">Trooping the Colour</a>, a formal military pageant performed by regiments of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth</a> and <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">British</a> armies to celebrate the <a href="/wiki/King%27s_Official_Birthday" title="King&#39;s Official Birthday">King's Official Birthday</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>377<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Boishakhi_Mela" title="Boishakhi Mela">Boishakhi Mela</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Bengali_New_Year" class="mw-redirect" title="Bengali New Year">Bengali New Year</a> festival celebrated by the <a href="/wiki/British_Bangladeshi" class="mw-redirect" title="British Bangladeshi">British Bangladeshi</a> community. It is the largest open-air Asian festival in Europe. After the Notting Hill Carnival, it is the second-largest street festival in the United Kingdom attracting over 80,000 visitors.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>378<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> First held in 1862, the <a href="/wiki/Chelsea_Flower_Show" title="Chelsea Flower Show">RHS Chelsea Flower Show</a> (run by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Horticultural_Society" title="Royal Horticultural Society">Royal Horticultural Society</a>) takes place in May every year.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>379<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="LGBT_scene">LGBT scene</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/LGBT_culture_in_London" class="mw-redirect" title="LGBT culture in London">LGBT culture in London</a></div>

<p>The first <a href="/wiki/Gay_bar" title="Gay bar">gay bar</a> in London in the modern sense was <a href="/wiki/The_Cave_of_the_Golden_Calf" title="The Cave of the Golden Calf">The Cave of the Golden Calf</a>, established as a night club in an underground location at 9 Heddon Street, just off <a href="/wiki/Regent_Street" title="Regent Street">Regent Street</a>, in 1912 and "which developed a reputation for sexual freedom and tolerance of same-sex relations".<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>380<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg/170px-Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg/255px-Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg/340px-Comptons-Of-Soho.jpg 2x" data-file-width="960" data-file-height="1280" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Comptons_of_Soho" title="Comptons of Soho">Comptons of Soho</a> during <a href="/wiki/Pride_in_London" title="Pride in London">London Pride</a> in 2010</figcaption></figure>

<p>While London has been an LGBT tourism destination, after <a href="/wiki/Sexual_Offences_Act_1967" title="Sexual Offences Act 1967">homosexuality was decriminalised</a> in England in 1967 gay bar culture became more visible, and from the early 1970s <a href="/wiki/Soho" title="Soho">Soho</a> (and in particular <a href="/wiki/Old_Compton_Street" title="Old Compton Street">Old Compton Street</a>) became the centre of the <a href="/wiki/LGBT_culture_in_London" class="mw-redirect" title="LGBT culture in London">London LGBT community</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Olson_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Olson-390"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>381<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/G-A-Y" title="G-A-Y">G-A-Y</a>, previously based at the <a href="/wiki/London_Astoria" title="London Astoria">Astoria</a>, and now <a href="/wiki/Heaven_(nightclub)" title="Heaven (nightclub)">Heaven</a>, is a long-running night club.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>Wider British cultural movements have influenced LGBT culture: for example, the emergence of <a href="/wiki/Glam_rock" title="Glam rock">glam rock</a> in the UK in the early 1970s, via <a href="/wiki/Marc_Bolan" title="Marc Bolan">Marc Bolan</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Bowie" title="David Bowie">David Bowie</a>, saw a generation of teenagers begin playing with the idea of androgyny, and the West End musical <i><a href="/wiki/The_Rocky_Horror_Show" title="The Rocky Horror Show">The Rocky Horror Show</a></i>, which debuted in London in 1973, is also widely said to have been an influence on countercultural and sexual liberation movements.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Blitz_Kids" title="Blitz Kids">Blitz Kids</a> (which included <a href="/wiki/Boy_George" title="Boy George">Boy George</a>) frequented the Tuesday club-night at Blitz in <a href="/wiki/Covent_Garden" title="Covent Garden">Covent Garden</a>, helping launch the <a href="/wiki/New_Romantic" title="New Romantic">New Romantic</a> subcultural movement in the late 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Today, the annual <a href="/wiki/Pride_in_London" title="Pride in London">London Pride Parade</a> and the <a href="/wiki/London_Lesbian_and_Gay_Film_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="London Lesbian and Gay Film Festival">London Lesbian and Gay Film Festival</a> are held in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-Olson_390-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Olson-390"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>381<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Literature,_film_and_television"><span id="Literature.2C_film_and_television"></span>Literature, film and television</h3></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/London_in_fiction" title="London in fiction">London in fiction</a>, <a href="/wiki/London_in_film" title="London in film">London in film</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_television_shows_set_in_London" title="List of television shows set in London">List of television shows set in London</a>, and <a href="/wiki/London_Television_Archive" title="London Television Archive">London Television Archive</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg/220px-Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg/330px-Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg/440px-Sherlock_Holmes_Museum.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes_Museum" title="Sherlock Holmes Museum">Sherlock Holmes Museum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Baker_Street" title="Baker Street">Baker Street</a>, bearing the number 221B</figcaption></figure>

<p>London has been the setting for many works of literature. The pilgrims in <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer" title="Geoffrey Chaucer">Geoffrey Chaucer</a>'s late 14th-century <i><a href="/wiki/The_Canterbury_Tales" title="The Canterbury Tales">Canterbury Tales</a></i> set out for <a href="/wiki/Canterbury" title="Canterbury">Canterbury</a> from London. <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a> spent a large part of his life living and working in London; his contemporary <a href="/wiki/Ben_Jonson" title="Ben Jonson">Ben Jonson</a> was also based there, and some of his work, most notably his play <i><a href="/wiki/The_Alchemist_(play)" title="The Alchemist (play)">The Alchemist</a></i>, was set in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-London_in_Literature_394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-London_in_Literature-394"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>385<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/A_Journal_of_the_Plague_Year" title="A Journal of the Plague Year">A Journal of the Plague Year</a></i> (1722) by <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Defoe" title="Daniel Defoe">Daniel Defoe</a> is a fictionalisation of the events of the 1665 <a href="/wiki/Great_Plague_of_London" title="Great Plague of London">Great Plague</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-London_in_Literature_394-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-London_in_Literature-394"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>385<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>The literary centres of London have traditionally been hilly <a href="/wiki/Hampstead" title="Hampstead">Hampstead</a> and (since the early 20th century) <a href="/wiki/Bloomsbury" title="Bloomsbury">Bloomsbury</a>. Writers closely associated with the city are the diarist <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Pepys" title="Samuel Pepys">Samuel Pepys</a>, noted for his eyewitness account of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_London" title="Great Fire of London">Great Fire</a>; <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">Charles Dickens</a>, whose representation of a foggy, snowy, grimy London of street sweepers and pickpockets has influenced people's vision of early <a href="/wiki/Victorian_era" title="Victorian era">Victorian</a> London; and <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Woolf" title="Virginia Woolf">Virginia Woolf</a>, regarded as one of the foremost <a href="/wiki/Modernist_literature" class="mw-redirect" title="Modernist literature">modernist</a> literary figures of the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-London_in_Literature_394-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-London_in_Literature-394"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>385<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Later important depictions of London from the 19th and early 20th centuries are <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Conan_Doyle" title="Arthur Conan Doyle">Arthur Conan Doyle</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes" title="Sherlock Holmes">Sherlock Holmes</a> stories.<sup id="cite_ref-London_in_Literature_394-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-London_in_Literature-394"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>385<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Robert_Louis_Stevenson" title="Robert Louis Stevenson">Robert Louis Stevenson</a> mixed in London literary circles, and in 1886 he wrote the <i><a href="/wiki/Strange_Case_of_Dr_Jekyll_and_Mr_Hyde" title="Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde">Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde</a></i>, a <a href="/wiki/Gothic_fiction" title="Gothic fiction">gothic</a> novella set in Victorian London.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>386<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1898, <a href="/wiki/H._G._Wells" title="H. G. Wells">H. G. Wells</a>' sci-fi novel <i><a href="/wiki/The_War_of_the_Worlds" title="The War of the Worlds">The War of the Worlds</a></i> sees London (and southern England) invaded by Martians.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>387<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Letitia_Elizabeth_Landon" title="Letitia Elizabeth Landon">Letitia Elizabeth Landon</a> wrote <i>Calendar of the London Seasons</i> in 1834. Modern writers influenced by the city include <a href="/wiki/Peter_Ackroyd" title="Peter Ackroyd">Peter Ackroyd</a>, author of <i><a href="/wiki/London:_The_Biography" title="London: The Biography">London: The Biography</a></i>, and <a href="/wiki/Iain_Sinclair" title="Iain Sinclair">Iain Sinclair</a>, who writes in the genre of <a href="/wiki/Psychogeography" title="Psychogeography">psychogeography</a>. In the 1940s, <a href="/wiki/George_Orwell" title="George Orwell">George Orwell</a> wrote essays in the <i><a href="/wiki/Evening_Standard" title="Evening Standard">London Evening Standard</a></i>, including "<a href="/wiki/A_Nice_Cup_of_Tea" title="A Nice Cup of Tea">A Nice Cup of Tea</a>" (method for making tea) and "<a href="/wiki/The_Moon_Under_Water" title="The Moon Under Water">The Moon Under Water</a>" (an ideal <a href="/wiki/Pub" title="Pub">pub</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>388<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The WWII <a href="/wiki/Evacuations_of_civilians_in_Britain_during_World_War_II" title="Evacuations of civilians in Britain during World War II">evacuation of children from London</a> is depicted in <a href="/wiki/C._S._Lewis" title="C. S. Lewis">C. S. Lewis</a>' first Narnia book <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lion,_the_Witch_and_the_Wardrobe" title="The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe">The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe</a></i> (1950). On Christmas Eve 1925, <a href="/wiki/Winnie-the-Pooh" title="Winnie-the-Pooh">Winnie-the-Pooh</a> debuted in London's <i><a href="/wiki/The_Evening_News_(London_newspaper)" title="The Evening News (London newspaper)">Evening News</a></i>, with the character based on a stuffed toy <a href="/wiki/A._A._Milne" title="A. A. Milne">A. A. Milne</a> bought for his son <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Robin_Milne" title="Christopher Robin Milne">Christopher Robin</a> in Harrods.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>389<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1958, author <a href="/wiki/Michael_Bond" title="Michael Bond">Michael Bond</a> created <a href="/wiki/Paddington_Bear" title="Paddington Bear">Paddington Bear</a>, a refugee found in <a href="/wiki/London_Paddington_station" title="London Paddington station">Paddington station</a>. A screen adaptation, <i><a href="/wiki/Paddington_(film)" title="Paddington (film)">Paddington</a></i> (2014), features the calypso song "<a href="/wiki/London_is_the_Place_for_Me" class="mw-redirect" title="London is the Place for Me">London is the Place for Me</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>390<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Buckingham Palace features in <a href="/wiki/Roald_Dahl" title="Roald Dahl">Roald Dahl</a>'s 1982 novel <i><a href="/wiki/The_BFG" title="The BFG">The BFG</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1235681985">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:var(--background-color-interactive-subtle,#f8f9fa);display:flow-root}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1;min-width:0}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1237033735">@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .sistersitebox{display:none!important}}@media screen{html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .sistersitebox img[src*="Wiktionary-logo-en-v2.svg"]{background-color:white}}@media screen and (prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .sistersitebox img[src*="Wiktionary-logo-en-v2.svg"]{background-color:white}}</style><div class="side-box side-box-right plainlinks sistersitebox"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409">

<div class="side-box-flex">

<div class="side-box-image"><span class="noviewer" typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Wikisource-logo.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/38px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="38" height="40" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/57px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/76px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" /></a></span></div>

<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><a href="/wiki/Wikisource" title="Wikisource">Wikisource</a> has original text related to this article:

<div style="margin-left: 10px;"><b><a href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Calendar_of_the_London_Seasons/Calendar_of_the_London_Seasons" class="extiw" title="wikisource:Calendar of the London Seasons/Calendar of the London Seasons">'Calendar of the London Seasons', by L. E. L.</a></b></div></div></div>

</div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:London_July_2010_(4818942309).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg/250px-London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg/375px-London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg/500px-London_July_2010_%284818942309%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736" /></a><figcaption>Opened in 1937, the <a href="/wiki/Odeon_Luxe_Leicester_Square" title="Odeon Luxe Leicester Square">Odeon cinema</a> in <a href="/wiki/Leicester_Square" title="Leicester Square">Leicester Square</a> hosts numerous European and world film premieres.</figcaption></figure>

<p>London has played a significant role in the film industry. Major studios within or bordering London include <a href="/wiki/Pinewood_Studios" title="Pinewood Studios">Pinewood</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elstree_Studios" title="Elstree Studios">Elstree</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ealing_Studios" title="Ealing Studios">Ealing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shepperton_Studios" title="Shepperton Studios">Shepperton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Twickenham_Studios" class="mw-redirect" title="Twickenham Studios">Twickenham</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros._Studios_Leavesden" title="Warner Bros. Studios Leavesden">Leavesden</a>, with the <i><a href="/wiki/James_Bond" title="James Bond">James Bond</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_(film_series)" title="Harry Potter (film series)">Harry Potter</a></i> series among many notable films produced here.<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>392<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-filmlondon_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-filmlondon-402"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>393<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Working_Title_Films" title="Working Title Films">Working Title Films</a> has its headquarters in London. A <a href="/wiki/Post-production" title="Post-production">post-production</a> community is centred in <a href="/wiki/Soho" title="Soho">Soho</a>, and London houses six of the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Visual_effects" title="Visual effects">visual effects</a> companies, such as <a href="/wiki/Framestore" title="Framestore">Framestore</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>394<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/The_Imaginarium" title="The Imaginarium">The Imaginarium</a>, a digital performance-capture studio, was founded by <a href="/wiki/Andy_Serkis" title="Andy Serkis">Andy Serkis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>395<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> London has been the setting for films including <i><a href="/wiki/Oliver_Twist_(1948_film)" title="Oliver Twist (1948 film)">Oliver Twist</a></i> (1948), <i><a href="/wiki/Scrooge_(1951_film)" title="Scrooge (1951 film)">Scrooge</a></i> (1951), <i><a href="/wiki/Peter_Pan_(1953_film)" title="Peter Pan (1953 film)">Peter Pan</a></i> (1953), <i><a href="/wiki/One_Hundred_and_One_Dalmatians" title="One Hundred and One Dalmatians">One Hundred and One Dalmatians</a></i> (1961), <i><a href="/wiki/My_Fair_Lady_(film)" title="My Fair Lady (film)">My Fair Lady</a></i> (1964), <i><a href="/wiki/Mary_Poppins_(film)" title="Mary Poppins (film)">Mary Poppins</a></i> (1964), <i><a href="/wiki/Blowup" title="Blowup">Blowup</a></i> (1966), <i><a href="/wiki/A_Clockwork_Orange_(film)" title="A Clockwork Orange (film)">A Clockwork Orange</a></i> (1971), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Long_Good_Friday" title="The Long Good Friday">The Long Good Friday</a></i> (1980), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Great_Mouse_Detective" title="The Great Mouse Detective">The Great Mouse Detective</a></i> (1986), <i><a href="/wiki/Notting_Hill_(film)" title="Notting Hill (film)">Notting Hill</a></i> (1999), <i><a href="/wiki/Love_Actually" title="Love Actually">Love Actually</a></i> (2003), <i><a href="/wiki/V_for_Vendetta_(film)" title="V for Vendetta (film)">V for Vendetta</a></i> (2005), <i><a href="/wiki/Sweeney_Todd:_The_Demon_Barber_of_Fleet_Street" title="Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street">Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street</a></i> (2008), and <i><a href="/wiki/The_King%27s_Speech" title="The King&#39;s Speech">The King's Speech</a></i> (2010). Notable actors and filmmakers from London include <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Chaplin" title="Charlie Chaplin">Charlie Chaplin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock" title="Alfred Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Caine" title="Michael Caine">Michael Caine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Julie_Andrews" title="Julie Andrews">Julie Andrews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Sellers" title="Peter Sellers">Peter Sellers</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Lean" title="David Lean">David Lean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Julie_Christie" title="Julie Christie">Julie Christie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gary_Oldman" title="Gary Oldman">Gary Oldman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emma_Thompson" title="Emma Thompson">Emma Thompson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guy_Ritchie" title="Guy Ritchie">Guy Ritchie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Nolan" title="Christopher Nolan">Christopher Nolan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Rickman" title="Alan Rickman">Alan Rickman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jude_Law" title="Jude Law">Jude Law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Helena_Bonham_Carter" title="Helena Bonham Carter">Helena Bonham Carter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Idris_Elba" title="Idris Elba">Idris Elba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Hardy" title="Tom Hardy">Tom Hardy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Radcliffe" title="Daniel Radcliffe">Daniel Radcliffe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Keira_Knightley" title="Keira Knightley">Keira Knightley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Riz_Ahmed" title="Riz Ahmed">Riz Ahmed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dev_Patel" title="Dev Patel">Dev Patel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Kaluuya" title="Daniel Kaluuya">Daniel Kaluuya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Holland" title="Tom Holland">Tom Holland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis" title="Daniel Day-Lewis">Daniel Day-Lewis</a>. Post-war <a href="/wiki/Ealing_comedies" title="Ealing comedies">Ealing comedies</a> featured <a href="/wiki/Alec_Guinness" title="Alec Guinness">Alec Guinness</a>, from the 1950s <a href="/wiki/Hammer_Film_Productions" title="Hammer Film Productions">Hammer Horrors</a> starred <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Lee" title="Christopher Lee">Christopher Lee</a>, films directed by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Powell" title="Michael Powell">Michael Powell</a> included the London-set early <a href="/wiki/Slasher_film" title="Slasher film">slasher</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Peeping_Tom_(1960_film)" title="Peeping Tom (1960 film)">Peeping Tom</a></i> (1960), the 1970s comedy troupe <a href="/wiki/Monty_Python" title="Monty Python">Monty Python</a> had film editing suites in Covent Garden, while since the 1990s <a href="/wiki/Richard_Curtis" title="Richard Curtis">Richard Curtis</a>'s rom-coms have featured <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Grant" title="Hugh Grant">Hugh Grant</a>. The largest cinema chain in the country, <a href="/wiki/Odeon_Cinemas" title="Odeon Cinemas">Odeon Cinemas</a> was founded in London in 1928 by <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Deutsch" title="Oscar Deutsch">Oscar Deutsch</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>396<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/BFI_IMAX" title="BFI IMAX">BFI IMAX</a> on the <a href="/wiki/South_Bank" title="South Bank">South Bank</a> is the largest cinema screen in the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>397<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_Film_Awards" title="British Academy Film Awards">British Academy Film Awards</a> (BAFTAs) have been held in London since 1949, with the <a href="/wiki/BAFTA_Fellowship" title="BAFTA Fellowship">BAFTA Fellowship</a> the Academy's highest accolade.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>398<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Founded in 1957, the <a href="/wiki/BFI_London_Film_Festival" title="BFI London Film Festival">BFI London Film Festival</a> takes place over two weeks every October.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>399<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p><p>London is a major centre for television production, with studios including <a href="/wiki/Television_Centre,_London" title="Television Centre, London">Television Centre</a>, <a href="/wiki/ITV_Studios" title="ITV Studios">ITV Studios</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sky_Campus" title="Sky Campus">Sky Campus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fountain_Studios" title="Fountain Studios">Fountain Studios</a>; the latter hosted the original talent shows, <i><a href="/wiki/Pop_Idol" title="Pop Idol">Pop Idol</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_X_Factor_(British_TV_series)" title="The X Factor (British TV series)">The X Factor</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Britain%27s_Got_Talent" title="Britain&#39;s Got Talent">Britain's Got Talent</a></i> (the latter two created by TV personality <a href="/wiki/Simon_Cowell" title="Simon Cowell">Simon Cowell</a> who starred as a judge in all three shows), before each format was exported around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>400<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>401<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Formerly a franchise of ITV, <a href="/wiki/Thames_Television" title="Thames Television">Thames Television</a> featured comedians such as <a href="/wiki/Benny_Hill" title="Benny Hill">Benny Hill</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rowan_Atkinson" title="Rowan Atkinson">Rowan Atkinson</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Mr._Bean" title="Mr. Bean">Mr. Bean</a></i> was first screened by Thames), while <a href="/wiki/Talkback_(production_company)" title="Talkback (production company)">Talkback</a> produced <i><a href="/wiki/Da_Ali_G_Show" title="Da Ali G Show">Da Ali G Show</a></i> which featured <a href="/wiki/Sacha_Baron_Cohen" title="Sacha Baron Cohen">Sacha Baron Cohen</a> as <a href="/wiki/Ali_G" title="Ali G">Ali G</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>402<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Many television shows have been set in London, including the popular television soap opera <i><a href="/wiki/EastEnders" title="EastEnders">EastEnders</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>403<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>

</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Museums,_art_galleries_and_libraries"><span id="Museums.2C_art_galleries_and_libraries"></span>Museums, art galleries and libraries</h3></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg/240px-Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg" decoding="async" width="240" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg/360px-Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg/480px-Kensington_Museums_aerial_2011_b.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2513" data-file-height="1749" /></a><figcaption>Aerial view of <a href="/wiki/Albertopolis" title="Albertopolis">Albertopolis</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Albert_Memorial" title="Albert Memorial">Albert Memorial</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall" title="Royal Albert Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Geographical_Society" title="Royal Geographical Society">Royal Geographical Society</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Art" title="Royal College of Art">Royal College of Art</a> are visible near the top; <a href="/wiki/Victoria_and_Albert_Museum" title="Victoria and Albert Museum">Victoria and Albert Museum</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_London" title="Natural History Museum, London">Natural History Museum</a> at the lower end; <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_London" title="Imperial College London">Imperial College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Music" title="Royal College of Music">Royal College of Music</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Science_Museum,_London" title="Science Museum, London">Science Museum</a> lying in between.</figcaption></figure>

<p>London is <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_in_London" title="List of museums in London">home to many museums</a>, galleries, and other institutions, many of which are free of admission charges and are major <a href="/wiki/Tourist_attraction" title="Tourist attraction">tourist attractions</a> as well as playing a research role. The first of these to be established was the <a href="/wiki/British_Museum" title="British Museum">British Museum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bloomsbury" title="Bloomsbury">Bloomsbury</a>, in 1753.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>404<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Originally containing antiquities, natural history specimens, and the national library, the museum now has 7&#160;million artefacts from around the globe. In 1824, the <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery" title="National Gallery">National Gallery</a> was founded to house the British national collection of Western paintings; this now occupies a prominent position in <a href="/wiki/Trafalgar_Square" title="Trafalgar Square">Trafalgar Square</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>405<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
